PS. Gigantic thank you to Jeffrey Schwinghammer for the amazing video footage & dealing with how awkward I can be on camera. Check out more of his work here: jeffreyschwinghammer.com
& special thanks to It's Just Great for offering a DJ set as part of the offered perks!


And if you read this far down, thanks for your commitment. V dedicated.

story:
Short Summary

Hi,

The picture above is the second I proposed to my girlfriend, Micaela. She's from the US, and I'm from Ireland. We both met in Paris and fell in love instantly.

Unfortunately, because of university, we have been living apart for the last year. During this time we have been planning our wedding. We have both been saving and working odd hours to ensure we could both have the dream wedding.

Sadly, we were thrown a curveball and Micaela had to undergo spinal surgery. She is on the mend, and working very hard to recover and rebuild after her operation. As I'm sure you're all aware, surgery can be quite expensive, and we had no choice but to put all our savings into making sure Micaela got better. As a result, our wedding funds are depleted, and so... I'm hoping that the kindness of strangers can help us turn this into the fairytale ending.


As it is we have placed many deposits on services, such as our reception venue and caterer, and we're hoping that you can help us make those final payments. Similarly, there are many costs associated with weddings that pop up and are beyond any imagined amount. 
If you can spare anything at all it would mean the world to us. We really don't know where else to turn. Thank you all for reading our story, and for contributing to our cause. :)

story:
I am very excited about this opportunity to learn from the Terra Madre delegates about how to expand the good food revolution and then share this experience with my community back home in Kentucky!

Dearest Friends!

My name is Jim Embry and I have been selected to serve as a USA delegate at Slow Food's Terra Madre and Salone del Gusto conference in Torino, Italy. Wow! What an honor this is as well as a grand opportunity for building international relationships. As a delegate I will meet people from 130 countries throughout the world who are passionate about and committed to sustainable agriculture, cultural preservation and good, clean and fair food for all. When I return home to Richmond, Kentucky I will share my experience with my community and continue the work of building the good food revolution here in the USA.

My goals are to engage in at least 25 community outreach efforts… such as speaking engagements, photo exhibits, house parties…before I go and after I return to share the Slow Food story and the remarkable Terra Madre experience. I already have speaking engagements lined up at universities, community colleges and coffee shops.

Who I am?

Two years ago I moved from Lexington to Richmond to live on a small family farm next to my 90 year old Aunt Bessie who I help provide some care. I have planted a fruit orchard, a large patch of wild flowers, native plants and sunflowers for the pollinators and have a large garden of all kinds of goodies. Since 2006 serving as the founder/director of Sustainable Communities Network (sustainlex.org), I have helped start 40+ community gardens, trained 400 teachers to create school gardens, organized annual local food summits and community garden tours, served on our local climate action plan team and the national planning committee for the Growing Food and Justice Gathering. My passion however is providing gardening, cooking and nutrition support to various women’s groups that serve women at risk. I work with women who are healing from domestic violence abuse, drug and alcohol addiction, homelessness, as well as provide support for teen mothers and their children. In 1972 I was a founding member of our local food cooperative, so I have been working on the joy and justice of this good food revolution for a long time.

I Need Your Support With Travel Expenses

Your support will help send me to the conference in Turin, Italy. In return, I will share Kentucky’s vibrant Slow Food culture with international audiences and bring back knowledge gathered from folks around the world.

As a delegate my housing and entry to the Terra Madre event are already paid for, but I need help with the other travel expenses. I will be attending this amazing event, but also spending time after in northern Italy visiting schools, farms and cooperatives to gain knowledge which I can bring back to my community. Your donations will help cover my air fare and expenses of extended stay in Italy which total about $2500.

Before I go and after I return, I will be sharing the message of the global sustainable food movement and my Terra Madre experiences with my community, neighbors, co-workers, friends and families. All contributors will be invited to a presentation of my travels upon my return, and each one will receive a thoughtful “thank you” gift that represents my experiences in Italy.

What is Slow Food?

Slow Food is a non-profit, grassroots membership organization that was founded in Italy in 1986 as a response to fast food and fast-food culture. It has grown into an international organization with more than 150,000 members in 150 countries. Slow Food strives to link the pleasures of the table with a commitment to protect the community, culture, knowledge and environment that make this pleasure possible.

Kentucky has a three active Slow Food chapters, Slow Food Bluegrass, Slow Food Lexington and Slow Food UK. In addition, our state has a Kentucky Proud program and a robust community of support for sustainable agriculture, good food and independent, local family farmers.

When my 90 year old aunt asked me “Jimmy you are going to Italy…well what is slow food?” I responded and said “Aunt Bessie, slow food is what you have been doing as a small farmer your entire life!”

Other Ways to Provide Support

I know that some of you might want to help financially but cannot do so at this time, and I appreciate that! But consider these other ways to support my efforts to bring the Terra Madre experience back home to Kentucky and the USA. After the Terra Madre gathering, I will be visiting local farms, schools and businesses near Torino to maximize my learning experience which I will share when I return home. My goal is to engage in at least 25 community outreach activities designed to share my Terra Madre experience with others, fulfill my responsibility as a delegate and continue to build on the joy and justice of good, clean and fair food  in my local community. Here is how you can help:

·  Speaking engagements: Please invite me to speak at schools, universities, faith congregations, community groups, restaurants, civic clubs, or conferences. I already have speaking engagements lined up at Somerset Community College and the University of Kentucky.

·  House Party: Organize a house party or fundraising dinner before I go(10/21) to Italy, or after I return (11/2). I would show pictures of my trip, talk about Terra Madre and the local food movement.

·  Photo Exhibits: Help me organize exhibits of my Terra Madre photos at galleries, libraries or schools in your community.

·  Social Media: Please feel free to share my campaign through your social media connections.

·  Watch this video:2014 Salone del Gusto/Terra Madre Pre-view and share with friends

·  Be Creative:and come up with other ways that you can contribute to this experience of bringing Terra Madre-Salone del Gusto and the international sustainable food movement home to Kentucky and the USA!

Please use the Indiegogo share tools to help spread the word about my campaign!

With lots of love and hugs!

Jim Embry

story:
Short Summary

Yemen is  a country that has a high rate of poverty and which its situation has not been improving. During the month of Ramadan, many families don't have the basic food that can help them fast this month. We are cooperating with local youth initiatives in Sana'a to provide critically in need families with food and clothes for the remaining month of Ramadan. 

This is a project that was started by a young Yemeni lady 2 years ago in Alberta, Canada. Our group (SofterHearts) is joining to support this great initiative for this year.


What We Need

We have gathered a list of food and recent prices that we have used so far to support the families we reached to. Most of the families we have contacted are unemployed, sick and with an average of 5 kids. 


Items/Food Supplies Canadian Dollar Yemeni Riyal
1/2 bag* of wheat $13.50 2700
1/2 bag* of flour $14.00 2850
Cooking oil $5.70 1150
Sugar $7.00 1400
Rice $6.50 1300
A box of beans $8.00 1650
Dates $3 600
Food for a family of 5-6 people/month $40.00 - $50.00 8,000 - 10,000
Clothes**
 $15.00
 3000
* See the gallery for sample pictures 
** For only ~$14 CAD : we can help a kid celebrate Eid Al Fitr with new clothes.

We have a list of over 20 families that are in a critical need. We aim to raise funds that would provide them with the essential food supplies for this month. The amount we need to raise is a minimum of $500 CAD.

We will transfer the donation to our partners in Sana'a and we will be obtaining up-to-date reports on where the money is being spent exactly.

About Us 

‘Gentler and Softer Hearts’ is a Yemeni-Humanitarian group based in Canada, and gathering youth who are advocating for cooperation, peace, and tolerance, which are values deeply rooted in the Yemeni and Islamic Culture, to support the Yemeni and local communities wherever we reside.
A group of students that is independent from and does not promote or support any political/religious ideology or party.
SofterHearts has taken different initiatives to provide emergency relief aid to different cities in Yemen, some of which were cooperated with international organizations such as Human Concern International, Islamic Relief, and  Health Partners international of Canada. We also worked on supporting youth initiatives in different areas, both overseas humanitarian projects as well as local community initiative.

Other Ways You Can Help

You can always help by:

  • Get the word out to your friends,
  • Keep us in your payers.
  • Contact us with your questions: 
    info@softerhearts.com
    facebook.com/SofterHearts

story:
The Project

In two weeks, I will be traveling to a small village outside of Yangon, Myanmar to document the work being done at the Colorful Flowers Garden (CFG) Children’s Home - and I need your help to do it. 

I’m raising $3,000 which will help fund a new roof for their kitchen and for the girl’s dormitory, as well as provide them with over two months worth of food for nearly 30 children. And - with the help of Global Populace - I’ve been matched with a Brand Sponsor, Mizuba Tea, who has agreed to fund my trip to the Children’s Home to document the impact of the money raised and create for them a video about their center to help them obtain future funding - but I have to successfully complete this fundraiser first.

The Purpose

So, you may be asking:

Why are you going there?

As a photographer and videographer, I love finding new opportunities and unique ways to tell people’s stories - and here I am able to not just share their story, but support their cause and their future. By creating a video for CFG that tells their story with beauty and clarity, they then have a new tool to use when pursuing future funding and outreach opportunities. 

What is Global Populace trying to do?

Global Populace connects storytellers with social brands to produce meaningful stories of impact around the world. With Global Populace, if a storyteller can crowdfund significant donations for a cause that the brand and storyteller are both passionate about, the brand rewards the storyteller with a travel grant to visit the cause and produce a story about the positive impact the crowdfunding has made.

Why CFG?

Global Populace first began working with CFG during a scouting trip in Southeast Asia last year and as a result I now have the opportunity to connect to and advocate on behalf of just a few of the projects that CFG has under way. 

What will the $3,000 go towards?

CFG’s director, Phyu Cyn, created a detailed list of what the money will be used for (which you can find below) - that includes the construction of two new roofs, a support pillar, and two and a half months worth of food including rice, meat, veggies, oil, etc for the nearly 30 children that their center supports.

Why not just give the money for your trip to CFG?

Much like marathon runners who raise money for a cause are rewarded by a Brand with a trip to a marathon, I am being sponsored by Mizuba Tea to document the impact of the money raised for this project - this documentary trip is my race. This not only helps donors like yourself see where all your money is going, but it helps spread the word about causes and projects like CFG, as the video I create will be used by CFG, Mizuba Tea, Global Populace and myself - making it available and known to numerous networks of new people, new ideas, and new opportunities. 

Who is the Brand Sponsor and what do they get out of it?

Mizuba Tea is a small tea company that directly sources its tea products from Japan and works to maintain close, honest relationships with their tea farmers. As my Global Populace Brand Sponsor, Mizuba Tea will have the opportunity to use the video and photos that I create telling CFG’s story for conscious brand marketing - helping to tell CFG’s story and why its important for Brands to work towards positive social impact.

Want to get involved or have questions?

Just visit the Global Populace website, www.GlobalPopulace.com ,  or email GP directly at GlobalPopulace@gmail.com !

Follow me on my journey on Instagram @timdoddphotography and through a daily blog on Global Populace's website.

About Colorful Flowers Garden Children’s Home

Naung Da Gar Village, Yangon, Myanmar

The Colorful Flower Gardens Children’s Home (CFG) is a family run organization based out of a small village just outside of Yangon, Myanmar (Burma). Founded in October of 2002, the organization works with children from communities throughout the country - both orphans and those from poor families - to provide them with access to education, healthcare, and safe living conditions, not to mention a supportive family living environment.

Donation Breakdown

Food (x 2.5 Months):

               Rice:    $340

               Cooking Oil:    $60

               Meat, Vegetables, etc:    $1,130

               Spices, Curries, etc:    $150

               Fish Paste:    $120

                                   Total:   $1,850

Roof Construction (Kitchen + Girl’s Dormitory):

               Roof Supplies:     $510

               Labor (4 people):    $135

               Kitchen Pillar:    $390

               Transportation:    $40

                                 Total:     $1,075

              Final Total: $2,925

story:
We are a group of 3 American volunteers seeking funding for a group of 12 to 15, poor farmers in Bohicon, Benin, West Africa.  This group owns 2 hectares of land south of Bohicon and proposes to create an irrigated farm for growing vegetables.  An irrigated farm makes a good profit because of seasonal price fluctuations in the price of vegetables.  The price of most vegetables doubles to quintuples at the height of the dry season (February to April) compared to the price during the height of the wet season (July to September).  With an irrigated farm, crops are produced during the dry season, and command the superior price.  There are few irrigated farms in the area because of the cost of the infrastructure for irrigating, namely a well of 70 to 80 meters (around 220 feet), a pump, generator, pipeline and an elevated (approximately 9 feet) water tank.  Because this group of farmers is very poor, they are also raising money for tools, seeds and fertilizer.  They are applying for a USAID Food Security Grant for the tools, seeds, training, and fertilizer.  This Indiegogo request is for the irrigation aspect of the project. 

The group plans to grow:  tomatoes, hot peppers, gboman (a dark green, leafy vegetable), carrots, okra, and lettuce. They also plan to grow moringa trees. Moringa leaves are a highly nutritional leaf that can supplement nutrient poor diets in Benin, but supply is small.  All of these crops are presently grown in the Bohicon area, and these farmers are familiar with their cultural practices.  The water table is approximately 80 meters.  They will need a pump that can produce 13.5 gal. per minute from approximately 260 feet and a generator that can power a pump of that capacity, which is why the pump and generator is fairly expensive.  This should give them adequate water for 2 ½ to 5 acres of irrigated crops.  This investment (both the Indiegogo and the USAID grants) has an estimated internal rate of return of more than 50%.  The group plans to use the profits from this farm to expand their acreage and to start planting some tree crops such as cashews and papaya. 

The group is committed to using this farm to expand employment opportunities in the community and growing fruits and vegetables that promote a healthier diet, given that malnutrition is a major problem in the region. By supporting this group, we are confident you are supporting  a development project that can have a meaningful impact on the lives of the group and their community.

to April) compared to the price during the height of the wet season (July to
September).  With an irrigated farm,
crops are produced during the dry season, and command the superior price.  There are few irrigated farms in the area
because of the cost of the infrastructure for irrigating, namely a well of 70
to 80 meters (around 220 feet), a pump, generator, pipeline and an elevated
(approximately 9 feet) water tank. 
Because this group of farmers is very poor, they are also raising money
for tools, seeds and fertilizer.  They
are applying for a USAID Food Security Grant for the tools, seeds, training, and fertilizer.  This
Indiegogo request is for the irrigation aspect of the project. 
The
group plans to grow:  tomatoes, hot peppers,
gboman (a dark green, leafy vegetable), carrots, okra, and lettuce. They also plan to grow moringa trees. Moringa leaves are a highly nutritional leaf that can supplement nutrient poor diets in Benin, but supply is small.  All of these crops are presently grown in the
Bohicon area, and these farmers are familiar with their cultural
practices.  The water table is
approximately 80 meters.  They will need
a pump that can produce 13.5 gal. per minute from approximately 260 feet and a
generator that can power a pump of that capacity, which is why the pump and
generator is fairly expensive.  This
should give them adequate water for 2 ½ to 5 acres of irrigated crops.  This investment (both the Indiegogo and the
USAID grants) has an estimated internal rate of return of more than 50%.  The group plans to use the profits from this
farm to expand their acreage and to start planting some tree crops such as
cashews and papaya. The group is committed to using this farm to expand employment opportunities in the community and growing fruits and vegetables that promote a healthier diet, given that malnutrition is a major problem in the region. By supporting this group, we are confident you are supporting  a development project that can have a meaningful impact on the lives of the group and their community.

story:
WE MADE IT!!

We made our goal at 1:20 PM on 7/27! Thank you to all who contributed! I so appreciate the support I have found from all of the communities I am a part of, new and old.

Money beyond $18,000

We just have a few hours left, but if you are on this page to donate and still can, I can use any help beyond $18,000 that I can get. I will use any money beyond $18,000 to purchase more supplies for my farm center, including a roto-tiller or small tractor (if I can find one in Haiti), more shovels and hand tools, more school and educational supplies, and more water catchment supplies to catch even more rainwater during monsoon season (I really can't have enough rain barrels and water catchment supplies). Thank you so much to all who have supported me! Here is the original main page for my campaign:

My story

Bonjour!

My name is Kenel Pierre. I grew up in Haiti with my family in the town of Hinche. Growing up I watched my parents and their neighbors work hard to grow enough food for us to eat with little left over to sell at the market. 

The soil was rocky and impacted by extreme flooding and dry seasons, as well as de-forestation.  My father’s only tool was a machete.  One day, when I was seventeen, he was killed in a farm related accident and our precarious life was made even more difficult. At this time my aunt, helped me to get into a high school in Hinche where I cared for the younger boys in an orphanage in exchange for room and board.  Through the orphanage I was able to attend a semester of college where I studied  agronomy. I had to leave the university for financial reasons but I moved on to work at an organization called Midwives For Haiti as a Creole teacher and translator. Here I met many good friends, including my dear American friend Sarah Taylor. Sarah was an volunteer at Midwives For Haiti from Portland, Oregon who was in Haiti to help deliver babies and teach midwifery. 

Through the orphanage and Midwives for Haiti, I met many other people who taught me English and offered me hope for both myself and my country.  They told me that my  country was once the richest colony in the world with so much food and many natural resources.  They also told me that the first people were killed by Christopher Columbus and replaced by my ancestors from Africa, who were forced to work on plantations until they fought for their freedom and won.  Decades of corruption, exploitation of the land and invasions left my country’s top soil in the sea, thousands dead and a proud people unable to grow enough food to feed their families.  Hunger, malnutrition cause one child in four to die before they reach the age of five.  Despite the efforts of many, my country is still the poorest nation in the western hemisphere.  And yet it is my home; the place of my family, my ancestors, familiar songs and much beloved landscapes.  I love my country and want to see her reclaim  the glory that was once hers. 

Many of my friends in Haiti are farmers and I have spent a lot of time with them seeing what they do and learning from them. After a while I realized that since they had not gone to school for agriculture, there was much missing from their knowledge of how to farm and how to take care of the land. I decided I wanted to become a farmer and a teacher so I could help the people of Hinche and the people of Haiti to farm better and to take better care of their land. So, when I met Sarah Taylor I explained to her my situation: how I would love to be a farmer and teach other farmers but did not have any real opportunity to be trained in the knowledge I needed to fulfill this dream. She knew of a program at Oregon State University and other farming resources in her hometown of Portland, Oregon in the United States. She shared my story with her friends and asked for help finding a way for me to gain the knowledge I needed to help Haitian farmers. She talked to many of her friends at Oregon State University, and together they created a scholarship for me to study agriculture through Oregon State University in Portland.

What I want to do for my community in Haiti

Studying agriculture provides me with the knowledge and understanding to contribute directly to the sustainable production of quality food for people, fiber for manufacturing, seed, and bioenergy crops. Working to improve agriculture is a key element in the effort to feed the world's growing population; crops play an ever-growing role in renewable energy production. Healing the land and producing local food in Haiti is of utmost importance to me. In my community I want to be at the forefront of a movement to take back the land, to rebuild its ecology and to create a truly local food system. I am so glad I have had this opportunity in Portland to become a true farmer and I am ready to go back home to Hinche in November of this year to help everybody in that community who is interested in growing their own food.

When I return to Haiti this September, I want to open a center for learning in Hinche where I will teach people about growing food and taking care of the land. The center will be a demonstration farm with a focus on teaching gardening, food security, and sustainable farming to the community of Hinche through many different learning activities, workshops, and community projects. My community of Hinche, and Haiti as a whole, is in need of much help with their food systems and education related to growing food. I want to use this learning center as a model farm to teach not only children, but all of the people in my community how to more sustainably grow food and other crops so we can start to repair our food system and countryside. In order to see these ideas manifest, I need your help. I do not have the funds to start this project, so I am asking all of you, my American friends, and friends of my American friends, to help me fund this project in any way you can. 

What I need to realize this dream

To realize this dream when I return to Haiti in September, I need to raise at least $18,000 to get started on a few tangible things in my community:

  • $5,000 to rent or buy a small plot of land in Hinche on which to create my small demonstration farm and learning center.
  • $5,000 for a second-hand truck, which will enable me to carry supplies and to drive women to the market to sell their food on market day.  Currently they walk many hours to sell a few things and then walk back. I want to help these folks and be able to transport goods and and training materials in my community.
  • $5,000 to build a small house and a classroom area so I can teach the people of Hinche sustainable farming and gardening practices.
  • $3,000 for gardening supplies, including seeds, hand tools, a roto-tiller or tractor, irrigation equipment, and water catchment systems.

With your help to raise funds for these items, I believe I can make a real change in the way the people of Hinche farm, eat, and think about their land. I will do everything I can to see this project come to life. Through hard work and the support of my friends, I will be able to expand the garden into a small demonstration site with regular classes and workshops.  It is my hope that your small investment will offer you the joy of knowing farmers are able to feed their children three meals a day and pay for their school. It is an investment in a smile and good help for a small country with a big heart. 

I will be hosting and leading small service groups in my town of Hinche in the coming years, with our first trip scheduled for early December of this year. These groups will focus on planting small orchards for schools and workshops for small rural villages, like theone I grew up in. If you are interested in these trips, please find me on Facebook or email me at Pierrekenel13@gmail.com

Please share this campaign with all of your friends through email, Facebook, or in person. We need your help to get the word out on this project!


Thank you so much!

Kenel Pierre

story:
Would you like to have fresh organic produce delivered to you every month? Would you like to be able to visit a local farm, and pick your own produce without extra fees? Don't have space for your own plot, but would like to work on ours in exchange for homegrown vegetables? Would you like to learn more about gardening to start a garden in your own yard? Would you like to pick up organic compost made from animals that you can actually visit, feed, and touch? This is how we live and we want to share it with our community! Help us build our community garden and learning farm.

We live on a small homestead in Indiana, after spending 6 years in San Diego with the Navy. While living in California, we made friends with master gardeners, and permaculturists that showed us how to fill in the gaps that modern farming leaves. My husband left the military due to injuries sustained to his back, and is now considered disabled.  This gave us the last push we needed to get out of the rush of the city. From the catching rain water to composting humanure, we have decided to live more sustainably. We are off to a great start by downsizing our material possessions, growing much of our own food, and using animals to help us fertilize our gardens and use food wastes. From solar power to outdoor showers, it's our mission to live more....with less. Along with that decision comes learning to make things for ourselves that we would once buy from big name stores. We want to know what we are putting in and on our bodies. We make goat’s milk soap, and our own lotions. We are ready to expand to help our farm provide for more than just our family, we want to grow for you!


We are ready to expand our garden to feed others through community supported agriculture (CSA). Your donation would help us spread the knowledge of the wonders of local, organic produce to our community. Our CSA depends on members who trust and invest in us every year by purchasing a share of our crops at the beginning of growing season. We then deliver their share of fresh eggs, milk, vegetables and natural body products every month But our farm is more than just lettuce delivery. We want our members to feel a part of the solution for feeding the world.  We want them to feel connected to their food and understand the steps we take to growing without chemicals. We want them to come to our farm and get their hands dirty (if the so choose) and bring their children to exeprience farming as it should be.
To expand to feed more families in the 2016 growing season, we will need:
A portable electric fence to help guard our precious greens from local wildlife. $500
A gutter and rain barrel system for irrigation and watering of livestock. $500
We are also ready to expand our goat herd. We love to have fresh goat’s milk available, and need a more sterile, dedicated milking and processing area. Your donation would help pay for a small shed that will house our milking stanchion, refrigerator, and storage for jars and other milking supplies. $2500

We want to share our knowledge with the next generation! We are well aware that the only way to feed the world successfully is through small organic farms. We are building a tiny house type structure that we want to open up to WWOOFers looking to learn more about permaculture and sustainable living. WWOOF(World Wide Opportunities on Organic Farms (WWOOF, /ˈwʊf/), or Willing Workers on Organic Farms,) WWOOF aims to provide volunteers with first-hand experience in organic and ecologically sound growing methods, to help the organic movement, and to let volunteers experience life in a rural setting or a different country. WWOOF volunteers ('WWOOFers') generally do not receive financial payment. The host provides food, accommodation, and opportunities to learn, in exchange for assistance with farming or gardening activities. The duration of the visit can range from a few days to years. Workdays average five to six hours, and participants interact with WWOOFers from other countries. WWOOF farms include private gardens through smallholdings, allotments, and commercial farms. Farms become WWOOF hosts by enlisting with their national organisation, and we have done so. We have currently wired our cottage to the grid, but are working toward having it solar/wind powered. your donation would help us to make this structure more green by funding our battery bank, windmill, and solar panels. It would also help us to fully finish the interior with wall panels and insulation. Your donation would also build the outdoor compost toilet and greywater friendly outdoor shower. $2000

Farm life is expensive. Our barn is old and leaks air and water, leaving our animals and equipment vulnerable to the elements. The back half is sagging dangerously and needs to be torn down and rebuilt with better trusses. The roofing is rusted and coming off in places, and the sidewalls are starting to rot where they touch the ground. These things are especially important for the safety of our visitors at the learning farm.Your donation would help replace the tin roof, plywood walls, and weatherproof the barn in general. $5,000

story:
Short Summary

Our Vision:  to empower and transform communities in Uganda through meeting personal needs and investing in individuals so their dreams come true

My name is Mukisa Rock and I am heading this project. I was born in Uganda and have lived in Masaka town or nearby villages all my life. I am now 23 years of age. It has always been a dream of mine to have my own land to farm and start a business in the community. I come from family that never had land or a house of their own. To get something to eat was a blessing from God. As a child, I would go steal mangos and other food to eat in order to survive. According to me poverty is having nothing and owning nothing at all in life and that is the life that my family was and is still living.

Most people do not want anything to do with farming. You have to be patient and work hard. However, I see many possibilities in farming because you can grow food, rear animals, and almost everything that is planted is on the market. This is how I want to eradicate poverty in my community. I can fight poverty and hunger in my family and country through this farming project. We already have land ready to be purchased and planted, but need is some help to get started. Together we can provide a food supply for this village, create employment, help eradicate poverty, and develop sustainable agricultural practices that can eventually be used in other communities as well. Join us in this project and allow our dreams to come true!

What We Need To Start

Our goal to start is $2,000, which includes:
  • Land ($1,000)
  • Transportation ($700)
  • Supplies ($200)
  • Labor ($100)

The Impact

This project will:

1) Provide a food source and healthy nutrition for the community

2) Create a sustainable income and employment opportunities

3) Empower the community to grow and develop

4) Introduce sustainable agricultural practices to the area

5) Fullfill our greater vision to empower and transform communities in Uganda through meeting personal needs and investing in individuals so their dreams come true

Mukisa Rock is partnering with Chelsea Green to reach their vision to empower and transform communities in Uganda. Chelsea has led several campaigns to volunteer in Uganda and help those living in poverty. You can find chronicles of her journeys on the website http://chelseagreen.me.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share our project on your facebook or twitter accounts
  • Spread the word and tell your friends and family about us, so we can join communities and make this project possible

Together we can transform Uganda!

story:
Summary

  • SOAR Youth Ministries is an organization dedicated to improving the lives of kids in the inner city of Knoxville, Tennessee. SOAR provides a free aftercare service to kids from the start of school right up into high school. 
  • This campaign is vital help these underprivileged kids be able to gain computer skills which are so important in this day and age. Most of these kids don’t even have computers at home, and a stable environment in which they can learn computer literacy would be instrumental in helping them achieve a brighter future. Currently, our computer lab is sub-par. There are old computers, some running Windows 95, which are useless for the development of our kids’ computer skills. In order to catch up to the times, they need to use the computers of these times. 
  • Your gifts, no matter how small, can go incredibly far. The computers and programs that we can buy with your money can help lead these kids in the direction of a good education and ultimately a good career.

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal at this time is $1000. However, we are flexible and we can use whatever funding we get. We will use the money to buy two more computers, software for these computers (such as Microsoft Office, Adobe Suite, etc.), and learning courses that the children can use. 

If you donate $5, you will receive a picture of the kids with their new computers in your email.

If you donate $10, you will receive a video of the kids with their new computers in your email, plus all other tiers’ benefits.

If you donate $25, you will receive a handwritten note from these children in the mail, plus all other tiers’ benefits.

If you donate $50, you will receive a picture frame with a special picture of these children with their new computers in the mail, plus all other tiers’ benefits.

If you donate $100+, we will make a special video directed solely to you, plus all other tiers’ benefits.

If we can’t reach our goal of $1000, we will still try buy as much as we can. Our computers cost roughly $450 and software can be very cheap. If we get more than our goal, we will use the money to buy even more computers and software. There is an unlimited use for money currently.

The Impact

This project represents ways we can better our communities through the use of technology. We can use technology to help lift a community out of poverty and into success.  With a model like this one, we can spread this idea to many other communities across America, and eventually the world.

Other Ways You Can Help

If don’t have money to donate, don’t worry! You can still help. To start, you can share this page on Facebook, Twitter, and other social media websites. You can also promote it on Indiegogo! Any publicity is good publicity and getting this campaign out there is vital to its success. So tell all of your friends about it!
story_txt:
Summary

SOAR Youth Ministries is an organization dedicated to improving the lives of kids in the inner city of Knoxville, Tennessee. SOAR provides a free aftercare service to kids from the start of school right up into high school. 

This campaign is vital help these underprivileged kids be able to gain computer skills which are so important in this day and age. Most of these kids don’t even have computers at home, and a stable environment in which they can learn computer literacy would be instrumental in helping them achieve a brighter future. Currently, our computer lab is sub-par. There are old computers, some running Windows 95, which are useless for the development of our kids’ computer skills. In order to catch up to the times, they need to use the computers of these times. 

Your gifts, no matter how small, can go incredibly far. The computers and programs that we can buy with your money can help lead these kids in the direction of a good education and ultimately a good career.

story:
Our Story

San Francisco's Homeless Youth Alliance is located at 1696 Haight St, their objective is to stop the homeless cycle at its roots by focusing on the homeless youth.  I created this campaign to support the HYA because this year they have lost 1/3 of their funding and are struggling to keep their doors open. Through this online donation page and by placing our bed with the HYA's message in a paid parking space on Haight St. we hope to create awareness of their efforts and gain enough funding to reach their goal of building homeless housing above their offices.  

The Impact

On the Week of Sept 26th to Oct 1st (9am to 6pm) in a paid parking space an actual bed will be on display in the Upper Haight (for those who are not from San Francisco, the Haight is a district of San Francisco that is known for its counter cultural vibe and as a place where the homeless youth generally congregate). If you are located in San Francisco please feel free to find us and say hi.  


What We Need & What You Get

All donations will support the Homeless Youth Alliance.


Other Ways You Can Help

Please pass this video on to friends and family.

The $1,000 goal posted above is our minimal goal.  With your help we are hoping to raise up to the 5 digit range.

story:
#What We Serve Again is:

The American economy has crumbled. Who better to rebuild it than those who have already served to protect it? We Serve Again is a challenge to our veterans to keep serving their country through entrepreneurship and engagment in their communities. 

 

#How Your Contribution Helps:

Your contribution will jumpstart the recovery by making all of the resources which are availabe to those who have served easy to access and utilise.

Your contribution will also help to restore lost dignity to those veterans sufferring from unemployment. 

Finally, your contribution will go a long way towards making veterans more employable by breaking down the language barriers that exist between the military, the education system, and businesses.

 

#More About We Serve Again

We Serve again shall be an interactive and engaging website that will be a continually updated portal of information for veterans, their families, and businesses who might not know about the benefits of working with those who have served. 

Big corporations tend to hire people based on their resumes, not their actual life experience, and that tends to keep vets, who have highly specialized skill sets, from getting employed by those companies. We Serve Again is to bridge that gap by challenging veterans to seek out new opportunities and ventures, and to simultaneously showcase their skills to businesses that may not have thought about hiring someone with a non-traditional life path. 

Report: Syracuse University makes the case for hiring vets.

Right now there is a 'bare bones' website up and running at www.weserveagain.com. Your contributions are needed to make it grow to its full potential. Features to be found on the full website will include:

  • Links to the thousands of organizations that are out there to provide help and support for veterans, as well as tutorials on how to best utilize them (ex: filing for VA disability or how to utilize the SBA Patriot Express program). 
  • The 'Road Map to Victory': An interactive map/flow chart that shows how everyone, veteran or not, can join the fight for our nation's recovery through veteran entrepreneurship.
  • Interviews, podcasts, and videos of veterans who have accepted the challenge to serve again and how it is affecting their lives and those of their families. 
  • A community of support where vets and organizations can reach out to each other: A major problem facing veterans is that they are unaware of how much this country is willing to support them for their service.

 

#About Jason Green

I’m a Navy Veteran who’s suffered the woes of unemployment twice, and I understand the helplessness that accompanies it. The second time was the worst. I'd completed my college degree and yet I could not find employment for 6 months. To go from leading a division of nuclear reactor operators in the Navy to getting that degree, but being unemployed, was humiliating.

Had I known about the tools available to me, I would have spent my time building a business instead of waiting for a phone call. Rather than toiling in anguish over what I should be doing with my life, and feeling like it was on pause, I could have been taking control of my life. I could have been living.

I don't want this to happen to anyone else. We Serve Again will be a one-stop shop that is heavily advertised to ensure that the message is out there for the rest of our country's veterans.

Unemployment sucks, so I developed this challenge as a way to give an answer to both veteran unemployment and our weakened economy.

 

#Join the Fight

A war isn't won with just its soldiers. Behind them is a vast network of support. Join the fight for our economy today by contributing to the cause. 

To get We Serve Again up and running, you can pledge anything -- from the cost of a movie ticket all the way up to a $5,000 sponsorship.

For just $25, you can help this project by leaving your own words of advice, encouragement, or thanks. These messages will be trickled out slowly through blog posts and videos so as to have maximum impact.

After you contribute, be sure to spread the word by 'like'ing us on facebook and following us on Twitter.

story:
My name is JD. I have a birth mother named Jan. Jan lives in Connecticut. My family in Connecticut is a working class family, and nothing has ever been easy. I was a ward of the state and separated from my family until 1996. I have three brothers and one sister. All of them lost their birth father when they were young (he died of heart failure). My birth mother Jan worked many jobs and struggled hard to raise her four children. She eventually re-married to an auto mechanic named Jim. All of the children in our family are of adult age now, but thing aren't any easier these days then they were in the 1990's or the 2000's. 

Jan lost her current husband. He died quickly, in just two weeks time. He spent that time in the ICU and left a $30,000 hospital bill. Then he left a $5,000 funeral bill. If that wasn't enough, Jan also lost her youngest son (my brother) Zach. When Zach died, there was another $5,000 funeral bill.

Jan works hard and lives with assistance. In this broken economy she can't get full time hours, and works as many hours as she can. All of my remaining siblings struggle to keep themselves above water, and even with all of our help, this burden of debt is too much for Jan to climb out of without help from other families who can understand how oppressive these organizations are and how impossible it is for poor families to get out of debts like this. With interest and fees over the past few years, it brings tears to the eyes. As long as the hospitals, collection agencies and funeral homes want their money (which they are entitled to), Jan can't get closure and move on with her life, and cope with the pain of losing both her husband and her son. 

Put simply, we're asking for America and the World to help us achieve a donation amount of $40,000 to put this burden down once and for all. We are asking for your help. $100, $20, $10, $5, $1, even 25 cents would help get closer to eliminating the bills from these tragedies and helping the family start healing. We are not a special family, so many families have hardship like this and live in a time when the economy is frightening and the future is frightening for all of us. Please help us, and we wish to pay it forward by helping other families who are suffering in just this same way. There are many famlies who need help, but this time it is our family's cry out for assistance.

If just 2,000 people donated $20.00 we would meet our goal. If just 4,000 people donated $10.00 we would meet our goal. We are asking you to spread the word for us, please. We are asking for you to make a donation of any amount, please.

If you can help, please make a donation of ANY amount, and pledge to pass this website link on to as many people as you can to help spread the word about our story.

If you can NOT help with a donation, we COMPLETELY understand that , but please pledge to pass this website link on to as many people as you can to help spread the word about our story.

Thank you all so much for your help and your compassion.

story:
Short Summary

Lauren and Wesley Wright are raising funds to finish the United Hearts Sustainable Fish Pond!  United Hearts is a community based project located in Awutu Bawjiase, Ghana. We believe that through supporting our local children, we will create a self sufficient community of healthy, educated adults committed to the future development of Bawjiase. 

Lauren's Story: Lauren has spent over 9 months is Bawjiase, and is the Volunteer Coordinator for United Hearts, and a Global Advocate for Mama Hope.  She has raised almost $40,000 through the amazing help of family and friends, for the new United Hearts Orphanage Facility, and for other sustainable projects.  The children and staff at United Hearts have completely changed her life, and she is fully committed to doing everything she can to connect them with the resources they need to support themselves and the community.

Wesley's Story: Wesley had the opportunity to visit  United Hearts during his spring break in 2011, and had a wonderful experience. He will be returning this summer for seven weeks, and can hardly wait to get there. Wesley is commited to seeing the fishpond completed, and believes in the future sustainability of United Hearts.

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise the last $1,500 in order to finish the Fish Pond when we return to Bawjiase on May 20th.  The first portion of the money for the fish pond was raised through Lauren's Birthday Wish, and a portion of Georgia Goonewardene's Birthday Wish.  The total cost of the project is $5,000, which provides the following:

-A plot of land where we will dig two fish ponds, one for Tilapia, and one for Mudfish.

- Labor costs for digging these ponds and a well, which will be used to periodically pump clean water into the ponds

- Fencing materials, nets, tilapia and mudfish fingerlings, and food for the fish for 6 months (before they are sold)

-A separate maintenence fund in case we face unforseen issues with the project.

To read the full project proposal with the exact breakdown of the project timeline, materials, and costs, email Lauren at info@unitedheartsghana.org.

Through contributing to this cause, you get the satisfaction of knowing that you are creating a source of sustainable income for an amazing community!  You can also receive updates on the progress of this project, through checking out the United Hearts Blog!

The Impact

We expect that after 6 months, the fish will be ready to sell and eat.  This will allow United Hearts contribute to the local economy, through selling the fish to restaurants and our supporters in the area.  It will also supplement the children's dietary needs, because tilapia and mudfish are a staple of the Ghanaian diet.  After using some of our revenue to reinvest in this sustainable project, we expect to have a total of over 2,700 GHS in profit.  This is enough to feed the children and staff at United Hearts for over 3 months.  

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word about this project!  Share it on facebook, tweet about it, and email this campaign to your friends and family.  Also check out our website (www.unitedheartsghana.org) to stay updated on our current projects, and learn about other ways you can get involved! 

**Please note, when you donate, you are contributing directly to the United Hearts Pay Pal Account.  Because Lauren Wright is in charge of the account, your confirmation email says you have donated to Lauren.  Lauren will transfer all funds directly into the United Hearts bank account upon completion of the campaign.

story:
Short Summary

The founder of the company is Mark Ogletree. Mark has worked the entire spectrum of the restaurant business. He has learned the business from the ground up. From his start as a dish washer up through the ranks of server, line cook, dining room supervisor, kitchen manager, assistant general manager and general manager. From food and kitchen management to total and complete cost controls through facilities management as well as sanitation and regulation compliance Mark has succeeded at all aspects of the restaurant industry. Mark's true talent lives in his focus of his guests, of what the guest wants, what the guest sees, and how to get it to them. In his steady and solid management style in following through on the promise of "EVERY GUEST LEAVES HAPPY." 

Our resident pastry chef, Jason Frothingham, graduated from the Notter School of Pastry Arts with a diploma in European Baking and Pastry and was trained by Chef Ewald Notter. Jason specializes in Artisan breads such as ciabatta, baguette, and sourdough as well as Breakfast pastries such as croissant, puff pastry and danish. In addition to his pastry diploma and training, Jason is also a Microsoft registered developer. His varied background will make him an unmatchable asset.

The Restaurant Management team is rounded out by several extremely talented restaurant people with background running the gamut from "hands on up through the ranks staff" as well as the more formal culinary school trained management members.

Our Mission is to provide the very best food, world class service and do it all with unyielding standards.

What We Need & What You Get

 Start-up   Expenses

 

Legal

$1,640

Stationery,   Menus, Brochures, etc.

$2,300

$4,595

$45,000

$45,000

 

 

Total   Requirements

$239,825

For contributing to our cause you will receive perks! See our perks chart to the right for your specific perk.

 

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help, Please help us get the word out. Tell everyone about us and suggest ways they can help either in contributions or spreading the word as well.

story:
Hello,

I am Hassan Salim Hassan aka Nguruzz, I am a freelance graphic designer, I mainly work online by participating on graphic design contests and also do some micro graphic design jobs on sites like fiverr. For this campaign, I want to upgrade my working space to a more modern setup.

The new setup will help me be more productive since I will be having the modern tools that I need as a graphic designer. The new set up will help me take my career to the next level and also open more doors of opportunities. 

I am looking forward to get new skills like logo designing with this setup grade, that is why I have include a wacom tablet as one of the items I am going to purchase.

With all this new setup and tools, I believe I can do more  work and increase my earnings as you know here in my country(Kenya) it very hard to find a good paying job. I also believe that I can make my dream come true of starting my own designing agency one day and provide work opportunities to other youths like me in my country.

I cannot do this all by myself and that's why I need your help to upgrade my working space and bring my dreams to a reality.

The funds raised here will be used to buy the following items and other accessories

ANY AMOUNT CONTRIBUTED WILL BE HIGHLY APPRECIATED.

IKEA DESK: price $646.99

Link to product: http://amzn.to/2eBeqVk

HP MINI: price $300

Link to product http://amzn.to/2eD37eu

LG Monitor: price $467.00
Link to product: http://amzn.to/2eBcDQi

Wacom Tablet: price $316.00
Link to product: http://amzn.to/2eKck4q

Chair: price $91.99
Link to product: http://amzn.to/2eJwTwH

story:
Update 5/5/12

WE ARE ADDING TO YOUR PERKS!!!

$5 perk will ALSO receive a coupon for a cup of coffee

$10 perk will ALSO receive coupons for 2 cups of coffee

$15 perk will ALSO receive coupons for 2 cups of coffee

$25 perk will ALSO receive coupons for 3 cups of coffee

This is all in ADDITION to the perks listed to the right! Please remember that sharing our page can be just as helpful as contributing! Use the links above to email, twitter, google+ and the share link to copy and paste into any other pages! Thank you so much for your support and please check the UPDATE TAB for more on the latest! 

Our Story

Brownies To Remember is our creation based on what we love to do and who we are inspired to help. We are a Mother/Daughter team who are combining ideas and talents to bring Brownies To Remember to life after the passing of our Mother/Grandmother and her sisters from Alzheimer's disease.

There are currently 5.4 million Americans living with Alzheimer's giving most of us at least a basic awareness of what it is. What a lot of us may be surprised to hear is that it is the 6th leading cause of death in the U.S. and the only cause of death that cannot be prevented, cured or slowed.

We want to do something about that, however, we are not doctors nor are we qualified to conduct research. We are just two ladies who love to bake from scratch and have some amazing brownies! So, our goal is to turn Brownies To Remember into a specialty bakery and website offering brownies, brownie cakes and other baked goods including vegan and gluten free varieties that donates 20% of the profits to the Alzheimer's Research Center in St. Paul, Minnesota which recently received national attention for their development on an intranasal insulin spray that improves memory.

What qualifies us to operate a bakery?

Brenda, aka Mom, has almost 30 years of experience in baking including successfully owning and operating 3 other bakeries. Her knowledge of the food service industry and baking on a large scale is key to the success of any bakery.

Elysia, aka Daughter, has been raised with a love of baking, been schooled in the business and accounting fields and has over 10 years combined retail and accounting experience.

What We Need & What You Get

While we have funding in place to cover equipment, we are still in need to cover the cost of construction to bring the location to code. This includes a fire suppression system, brand new men and women's restrooms, plumbing, electric and installation of a ventilation hood. Our goal is $50,000. Anything above our goal will be used on the starting supplies to make those incredible brownies! In the unfortunate event we do not reach our goal, the funds will still be used toward construction and/or supplies.

Though it may seem a lot to choose a location needing so much done, our chosen location is key to the success of Brownies To Remember. We are working with the developer of a seniors apartment complex which has available retail space on the first floor. The complex and surrounding area has numerous medical facilities and retailers that would make perfect customers or affiliates. The cherry on top is that Barberton is known for a strong community bond and support of senior citizens and their needs.

While EVERY donation gets our eternal appreciation, we will offer the perks listed on the right along with a personal thank you to those designated donations. What better way to not only thank you but show you what you have helped create by giving brownies!

The Impact

Enjoy a brownie. Fund research for Alzheimer's. It's that simple. Brownies To Remember is making a pledge to donate 20% of our profits to Alzheimer's research giving you one more reason to treat yourself and feel good about it!

Other Ways You Can Help

We appreciate help of ALL kinds! Whether you are able to donate or not you can also share our campaign to help us reach our goal! Please share our page with friends and family through the links above as it will get the word and our business name out to more people! Thank you for your support and donations! We will be able to do some great things with your help!

story:
We want to recognize the craft breweries of this great state with a well-made photo book suitable for your coffee table or those of your fellow Kansan beer aficionados.

We all earned bachelors degrees from one of the state’s leading universities. Jim went on to be a career US Air Force pilot, earning an MA in History and now flies for a major airline. Bob earned a degree in engineering, then an MBA and now runs one of the largest mobile dental practices in Texas. Charley lives in Overland Park and was in financial planning and is now self-employed.  Charley will help us on the marketing end of the project. He will also show up from time to time to help us drink the beer we can't finish.  :)

We are happy for all contributions to this effort. This is a project of love for us and we're excited to share the journey with you. We hope you will enjoy following our adventures as we document the small, but growing craft breweries in the state.  Funding for this effort will go primarily towards the production and distribution of the book. Our current estimate takes into account the costs of design, editing, formatting, printing, and marketing. Jim and Bob are more than happy to just be paid in beer!

Our goal is not necessarily to make a profit from this venture, but to fill a niche in the market and show off the great beers of Kansas!

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Feel free to follow us at our Untappd accounts and see what we've been drinking:

Bob: https://untappd.com/user/Sdmundis

Jim: https://untappd.com/user/JimCrutch

story:
Our Story

Sure, I need to raise money for myself, but there is something about Ms. Tonya Burrell that has sparked an extreme desire to help launch her business.  Ms. Tonya exemplifies what every entrepreneur should have and that is love and true heart.  She has to be one of the most amazing bakers/chefs that I have ever met.  Her giving spirit and the love that she puts into her food and presenting her food and pastries to others is something that more and more people should experience.  Even when she should be thinking of herself she is constantly supporting and promoting others on a daily basis.  Helping Ms. Tonya to launch her business would be a blessing to many people.  She is the creator of the most amazing cupcakes and cakes in all different shapes and sizes.  It is amazing to me to see how much she gives away for free when she really should be charging and that to me shows that she truly loves and believes in what she does and in turn causes others to believe.

Impact

Helping Ms. Tonya to Raise this money will make a difference in the lives of so many people.  Additionally Ms. Tonya would be able to reach more people and book in venues because she will be able to afford the license that she needs to serve food in public.

What We Need & What You Get

In order for Ms. Tonya to fully launch her business to more people, she needs to be licensed.  Being a single parent with one income,  the close to $450.00 that she needs to pay for the license is not an easy amount to come up with.  Additionally, she will need funds for marketing materials and products $500.00,

$150.00 for website - which include domain registration and web hosting for several years and build.

$3500.00 for a used van that she found which can be used for deliveries and transporting of her products.

$500 for additional baking supplies which include the ever popular request by the people who have tasted her cupcakes, shipping supplies.  

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word about this campaign to help Ms. Tonya Burrell.  Although this has Ms. Tonya as the administrator, the idea and all the info was conceived by DeeWorks.  I truly believe in Ms. Tonya and trust that you will too once you have experienced the love and passion that she puts into her food and pastries. 

Let's help Ms. Tonya, and by doing that, we are helping the world.

Be Blessed in Your Walk.

Please post on facebook, twitter, myspace, linkedin, wherever you have friends who can benefit from tasty treats in their lives.

story:
Wildcard Screen Printing Co.

3069 Freeport Blvd., Sacramento, CA 95818

530.304.4177 / brian@wildcardscreenprinting.com

www.wildcardscreenprinting.com

www.facebook.com/wildcardscreenprinting

 

My name is Brian Richards, I am 26 years old and a Northern California native, born in San Francisco, raised in Marin County and Davis and currently living in Sacramento.  I have worked as a screen printer in three different shops around Davis and Sacramento over the last seven years, including my last position as the lead printer/designer for a soccer company's print operation.

My roommate and I began building this business just over a year ago by purchasing equipment and supplies online and creating a screen printing studio out of the garage of the house we had been renting.  We set aside about $2K each of our student loans over the course of two semesters ($8K total) while we were attending Sacramento State in order to build the company to where it is today.  

Our clients have mostly been friends and fellow students from Sacramento State, as we have printed shirt orders for many different clubs and organizations affiliated with the school over the past year, here are just a few: Martial Arts Club, Sign Language Club, Public Relations Student Society, Institute of Electrical and Electronic Engineers, Optometry Club, Parks & Rec Majors, Xi Phi Chi Fraternity.  We have also been involved with several other clients, mostly through friends and word of mouth.

This summer, just weeks after I graduated (finally) from Sac State, and with the help and generosity of my Grandma and her husband, I was able to finance a move into the beautiful Land Park neighborhood of Sacramento, where I have just opened up my own storefront in an old commercial building across the street from McClatchy high school and down the block from Sacramento City College.

The next few months are crucial to the success of the company.  I have several friends willing to dedicate their time and effort to help me, but I am in need of some available capital to ensure the company's survival by obtaining a few more design programs and small pieces of equipment.  With the help of indiegogo and those willing to take a chance on our future, I believe this company will grow into a permanent Land Park fixture and soon could be expanding into the job creator that the surrounding area desperately needs.  Thank you for you help, I deeply appreciate it, this has been a dream of mine for a long time.

story:
How You Can Help:

Step 1: Buy a perk (right side of this web page).

  • For $250 you can get a custom Ride Jersey from our events.
  • For $100 you can get you own sport lounge chair, take it to all the events you enjoy.

Step 2: Spread the word, Please tell a friend about what we’re doing.

Step 3: Like us on facebook and share with your friends.

 

WHY?  Supporting those that Fought for our Freedom:

SAG 4 Recovery was founded in the spring of 2012. Our mission at SAG 4 Recovery is to honor our Wounded Veterans together with their families by providing to them at no charge Cycling event services, equipment and support to major planned veteran Cycling events that they participate in. However, to allow us to continue providing this fabulous and well deserved support we need your help. So please give as much as you are able to show your support and help our brave wounded heroes achieve their goals and succeed in their recovery, but most of all to put a smile on their faces. It's worth it and let me tell every dollar you donate will go a long way in allowing us to achieve our aim of 3.5 million dollars to operate in 2013. Thank you all for taking time out to read this and God bless America and our hero veterans who have all served our great country in the past and now need your help and support"

 

SAG 4 Recovery will provide upon funding goal is met:

  • Full service mobile custom cycling service shop, geared to support special needs participants and make specialty parts readily available to prevent Our Wounded Veterans and Heroes from leaving a ride due to equipment failure.
  • SAG Wagon Support Vehicles and trained staff will be there for participants during Cycling events, whether it’s fixing a flat or just helping a rider with a push up that big hill, we will have the people there to provide the support.
  • Mobile Event office for coordinators is a key function for ongoing events that will be able to move from one location to the next. Ability to provide event coordinators with the capability of staying connected for Mobile communications and media support.
  • Mobile EMT-Support room located off of the Event office for immediate response to participants. This feature will be staffed by a state registered EMT-P to allow for instant communication with local Fire and Rescue Groups.
  • Ice on demand availability from a Professional Ice Maker will provide all the Ice any event could need.
  • Crowd and Road control devices with both high visibility traffic cones and belted stanchions to make safety a prime target at any event.
  • Public Audio System that will allow your message to be heard amongst even the largest crowds or mobility into conference halls for smaller events.
  • SAG Wagon vehicles are transported on a trailer to minimize fuel consumption that transforms to a 30" high stage with ADA standards at the event site.
  • Shade tents, chairs and tables.
  • Small retail shop to offer replacement shoes, helmets, and items that can become damaged or lost during a ride.
  • And trust me the list goes “On n’ On”.

 

What We Need:

Donate and your tax-deductible gift will help us complete our missions to support our Wounded Warriors. 100% of your money will go to direct expenses of the 2013 cycling event season. We are raising money two ways: corporate sponsors and individual donations (like yours).

$600,000  Custom Gold Rush 53’ Stacker Semi Trailer and Peter Built 587 Tractor

$335,000  Sag Wagon Support Vehicles

$350,000  Marketing Vehicles and Equipment

$500,000  Bicycle Parts (Remember SAG4Recovery is available at no charge)

$15,000    Event Traffic Control Equipment

$600,000  Event and Transit Fuel

$365,000  Staff Overnight Hotels

$450,000  Staff of 12, Payroll

$110,000  Misc. Tools and Event Support Equipment

$40,000    Public Audio System

$50,000    Marketing Merchandise

$20,000    Ice Making Equipment

$40,000    Mobile Office Equipment

$50,000    Medical Equipment

======================

$3.525.000  Total

 

Our Core Values:

 

 

How You Can Help:

Step 1: Buy a perk (right side of this web page).

  • For $250 you can get a custom Ride Jersey from our events.
  • For $100 you can get you own sport lounge chair, take it to all the events you enjoy.

Step 2: Spread the word, Please tell a friend about what we’re doing.

Step 3: Like us on facebook and share with your friends.

 

Fun After the long ride:

Mobile EMT-Support room located off of the Event office for immediate response to participants. This feature will be staffed by a state registered EMT-P to allow for instant communication with local Fire and Rescue Groups.
Ice on demand availability from a Professional Ice Maker will provide all the Ice any event could need.
Crowd and Road control devices with both high visibility traffic cones and belted stanchions to make safety a prime target at any event.
Public Audio System that will allow your message to be heard amongst even the largest crowds or mobility into conference halls for smaller events.
SAG Wagon vehicles are transported on a trailer to minimize fuel consumption that transforms to a 30" high stage with ADA standards at the event site.
Shade tents, chairs and tables.
Small retail shop to offer replacement shoes, helmets, and items that can become damaged or lost during a ride.
And trust me the list goes “On n’ On”.
 
What We Need:
Donate and your tax-deductible gift will help us complete our missions to support our Wounded Warriors. 100% of your money will go to direct expenses of the 2013 cycling event season. We are raising money two ways: corporate sponsors and individual donations (like yours).
$600,000  Custom Gold Rush 53’ Stacker Semi Trailer and Peter Built 587 Tractor
$335,000  Sag Wagon Support Vehicles
$350,000  Marketing Vehicles and Equipment
$500,000  Bicycle Parts (Remember SAG4Recovery is available at no charge)
$15,000    Event Traffic Control Equipment
$600,000  Event and Transit Fuel
$365,000  Staff Overnight Hotels
$450,000  Staff of 12, Payroll
$110,000  Misc. Tools and Event Support Equipment
$40,000    Public Audio System
$50,000    Marketing Merchandise
$20,000    Ice Making Equipment
$40,000    Mobile Office Equipment

$50,000    Medical Equipment
======================

$3.525.000  Total
 
Our Core Values: 
 
 
How You Can Help: 
Step 1: Buy a perk (right side of this web page).

For $250 you can get a custom Ride Jersey from our events.
For $100 you can get you own sport lounge chair, take it to all the events you enjoy.
Step 2: Spread the word, Please tell a friend about what we’re doing.
Step 3: Like us on facebook and share with your friends.
 
Fun After the long ride:

story:
“The only thing necessary for the triumph of evil is for good men to do nothing.”

-          Edmund Burke

 

Dear Friend,

 

    As an aspiring philanthropist, I believe that it is our obligation to do right by others. This not only includes the members of our neighborhood, our places of worship or our workplace; but also the members of our global community. It is only with the success of a functional global community that true freedom and prosperity can strive.

    Along with a prosperous society, comes a great deal of responsibility. A duty to uphold the rights and freedoms of others is extremely crucial. However, with responsibility comes expectations, and it is with those expectations that we must tread carefully. We must ensure that we will not make promises that we cannot entirely keep.

   I have made a promise to my community; to people in need and to myself. I have made a promise that will undoubtedly change lives for the better. This promise is most certainly attainable, but as a commonly quoted phrase states, “It takes a village to raise a child.”

    As a part of my village, my community, I am asking you to assist me in keeping my promise to the children of Uganda. This fall I will travel to their home in Bugembe and work alongside them as a mentor and a friend. Stephen and Dinah Wante opened their home to these children, whose parents have passed as a result of genocide or AIDS. While at El Shadai Foster Home, the 30 children attend school, learn to be self-sustainable and are cared for by two loving guardians; “Uncle Stephen & Auntie Dinah”. These children are a beacon of hope for others in the darkness that often grips rural Africa.

    It is my hope that you will stand up with me today. It is the children’s hope that you will take action against poverty and injustice. Together we can build the foundation of a better future for all of our brothers and sisters. There are more than 2 million orphans (18 and under) in Uganda. We may not be able to save all the children of the world, but we can definitely make a huge difference in the lives of those at El Shadai.

 

Thank you for your time and consideration.

-Paul

story:
We are BACK to launch our 2nd Campaign!!

Greetings! My name is Stasha. I am a healer from California and the founder of an organization for children called Healing with Beats.

Healing with Beats is a program that raises awareness and offers healing to children worldwide through music. We are looking for help to expand our healing space by adding a large self-sustaining Garden!

What We Need:

We only need $3,333.33 to expand our gardens!

$2,000 of this goes to rent on the new space.

$1,000 of this goes to a safe vehicle to transport items to local markets.

$333.33 of this goes to maintenance on the gardens!

The Impact:

Healing with Beats Gardens will be donating 10% of all sales to Local Irish charities, as well as once a month we will be donating to different children's charities abroad!

What you get:

Donations start at $1! Everyone who donates will receive a gift!

For $1 you will receive: 30 minute Guided Healing meditation (mp3)

For $5 you will receive:One package of our Herbal Bath Salts

For $10 you will receive: One bottle of our Crystal Essence or Herbal Oils

For $25 you will receive: Herbal Gift Set- Small (variety of items above)

For $50 you will receive: Herbal Gift Set- Large (items above & a BONUS)!

For $100 you will receive: Herbal Gift Set- MEGA (items above & 2 BONUS')!

For a donation of $1,111.11 you can become a Partner in the Healing with Beats family! Funds that you donate will go to seeds and maintenance on the gardens. 10 % of all profits made from seeds you help purchase will be given directly to YOU or the charity of your choice! This will be valid for one year from the time of your donation.

Please feel free to contact me with any questions you may have.

Direct donations can be made via PayPal at: healingwithbeats@gmail.com

Blessings & Beats...WE LOVE YOU! ♫♪•*stasha ♫♪•*
http://healingwithbeats.us

Other Ways You Can Help:

We understand that some people can’t contribute cash, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help!

Please help us get the word out & make some noise about our campaign!

Please use the Indiegogo share tools to share the links & video with your friends and family, it would mean the world to us!


To find out more information, please check out our campaign at:
http://indiegogo.com/healingbeatsgardens
