Faire de vos voyages
un enrichissement personnel : Échappée Australe, futur tour
opérateur.

Vous aussi vous trouvez que payer entre 3 000 et 4 000 euros pour passer 10 jours en Afrique du Sud à 2 (sans les billets d'avion), c'est cher? Vous aussi vous pensez que payer cette somme pour des voyages dans des hôtels sans charme, c'est cher? Vous n'arrivez pas à trouver des agences de voyages ou des voyagistes qui vous font réellement aller en dehors des zones touristiques ? Nous avons rencontré les mêmes problèmes. C'est pourquoi nous voulons ouvrir un tour-opérateur abordable pour vendre des voyages en Afrique Australe et vers les îles de l'Océan Indien.
A titre de comparaison, nous pouvons vous envoyer en Afrique du Sud pour 2 000 euros pour 2 personnes. Nous privilégions la rencontre avec les locaux et les autres voyageurs et tenons à ce que les logements apportent un plus au voyage : originalité, situation, charme ou favorisant les échanges d'expériences. Nous avons testé les logements que nous proposons et les avons validés en fonction de ces critères ! Nous avons traversé l'Afrique Australe en mode routard à plusieurs reprises (9 mois au total): à pieds, en vélo, en stop, en transports locaux et en voiture. Nous avons testé toutes sortes de logements : chez l'habitant, en guest houses, en B&B, en backpackers, dans des lodges, dans des camping… Nous avons également testé des activités originales. Nous connaissons les destinations que nous proposons et avons déjà organisé des voyages pour des amis : ils ont adoré !


Sommaire
Notre projet
Qui sommes nous?
Notre vision

Les récompenses

Pour un don de 50 USD (43 €): nous vous enverrons un email de remerciement 
Pour un don de 250 USD (216 €): nous vous offrons une réduction de 5% 
Pour un don de 500 USD (432 €): nous vous offrons une réduction de 10%
Pour un don de 2 000 USD (1 730€): nous vous ferons découvrir le Western Cape (pour 2 personnes)
Pour un don de 2 200 USD (1 900€): nous vous ferons découvrir l'Eastern Cape (pour 2 personnes)
Pour un don de 3 000 USD (2 590€): nous vous emmènerons de Cape Town à Port Elizabeth (pour 2 personnes)


Retrouvez-nous sur internet
Quels sont les risques pour ce projet?

FAQ - Foire Aux Questions


Les voyages proposés sont pour combien de personnes ?

Les réductions proposées sont-elles valables pour moi et mon conjoint ?
Peut-on adapter les voyages que vous proposez selon nos envies ?
Pour les voyages proposés, peut-on choisir la date qui nous convient ?
Y a t-il un surcoût en fonction de la date du voyage ?

Quelle est la meilleure période pour observer les baleines ?





Notre projet

Nous avons pour
projet d'ouvrir un tour-opérateur spécialisé sur l'Afrique
Australe. Nous vendrons nos voyages uniquement sur internet (pas
d'agence physique). Les voyages seront à la carte : chaque
voyage est unique et est élaboré avec le client afin qu'il lui
corresponde. Les voyages seront composés des prestations suivantes :
location d'une voiture, logements et activités. Les logements seront
principalement des backpackers, des guest houses et des bed &
breakfasts. L'important pour nous est que le logement apporte un vrai
plus à l’expérience : originalité, positionnement ou tout
simplement un lieu propice aux rencontres et au partage. Les
activités pourront être directement réservées avec nous. Nous
souhaitons proposer des voyages à des tarifs abordables : nous
ne passerons pas par des intermédiaires.



Qui sommes nous?

Nous sommes deux
personnes sur ce projet : 


Amandine
Deslangles qui, après avoir obtenu un bac STG en comptabilité et
gestion des entreprises, a obtenu un diplôme Ventes et Productions
Touristiques. Elle a également plusieurs expériences en agence de
voyages et en tour opérateur.
Clément Pilchen,
diplômé d'une école d'ingénieurs spécialisés en gestion de
projet et innovation, a géré des projets dans des secteurs variés
(BTP, milieu pharmaceutique, aide en création d'entreprise) avant de
travailler 2 années dans le secteur informatique.



Depuis 2010, nous
travaillons sur ce projet de tour opérateur. Nous sommes ainsi
partis une 1e fois en Afrique du Sud et au Swaziland en 2010 pour
connaître ces pays. En 2013 et 2014, nous sommes retournés pendant
7 mois en Afrique Australe dans le but de trouver les partenaires
fiables pour les différentes prestations que nous proposerons. Nous
sommes ainsi certains qu'il y a un potentiel inexploité dans ces pays
pour un tourisme différent, en adéquation avec notre vision.



Notre vision

Nous sommes partis
du constat suivant : les voyages proposés en Afrique Australe
par les agences de voyages sont tous les mêmes et ne permettent pas
de véritablement connaître les pays. De plus, ils sont généralement
assez chers compte tenu du coût de la vie de ces pays.

Nous voulons
proposer la découverte de lieux insolites et réellement hors des
sentiers battus. Nous nous basons sur nos expériences et nos
connaissances de cette région du monde. Nous voulons privilégier
les rencontres et les échanges, que ce soit avec les populations
locales ou avec les autres voyageurs. Nous pensons que le voyage doit
être un enrichissement personnel, c'est pourquoi ce point nous est
important.

L'Afrique Australe
n'est pas forcément une région très connue. La sécurité de nos
clients sera au cœur de nos prestations. C'est pourquoi nous avions
décidé de réellement explorer ces pays et de travailler avec des
partenaires en qui nous pouvons avoir confiance. 


Enfin la confiance
du client est primordiale. Personne n'est à l'abri d'un manquement
de son voyagiste, en particulier sur internet. Pour éviter tout
problème, notre mode de fonctionnement sera le suivant : dès
que nous recevrons l'argent du client, nous le reverserons à nos
prestataires afin de finaliser la transaction. Cela peut sembler
logique mais, bien souvent, les versements de l'argent aux
prestataires s'effectuent par période (par exemple : tous les
trois mois). Cela peut entraîner des dettes que le voyagiste ne
serait pas en mesure de couvrir et le client risque de se retrouver
sans logements une fois dans le pays… L'autre aspect de cette
confiance sera de souscrire à une garantie financière à hauteur de
200 000€. Cette garantie aura pour objectif de payer les dettes en
cas de manquement de l'entreprise. Le client n'aura donc aucune
mauvaise surprise avec nous !



Les récompenses

Par le crowdfunding,
nous vous proposons de devenir client avant l'heure : que ce
soit par des réductions sur les voyages que nous vendrons ou tout
simplement par des voyages à prix réduits.
Nous proposons ainsi
de vous organiser des voyages en Afrique du Sud pour 2 personnes. 
 

Pour un don de 50 USD (43 €): Nous vous enverrons un email de remerciement Toute contribution est la bienvenue et nous aidera énormément. C'est pourquoi nous vous enverrons un email pour vous remercier, dès que la campagne de financement sera terminée. De plus, nous vous tiendrons informé de l'avancé de notre projet. 
 
Pour un don de 250 USD (216 €): Nous vous offrons une réduction de 5% Une fois notre tour opérateur ouvert, vous bénéficierez d'une réduction de 5% à valoir sur le voyage de votre choix (dont les voyages sur mesures) à destination de l'Afrique Australe et sur les îles de l'Océan Indien. Par exemple, le voyage que nous proposons actuellement pour un don de 2 000 USD (environ 1 730 € / Western Cape en voiture pour 2 personnes) coûtera environ 2 400 USD (environ 2 000 €). Cette différence provient des charges et taxes que nous auront une fois le tour opérateur ouvert. Avec votre réduction de 5%, vous pourrez bénéficier de ce voyage au prix de 2 250 USD (environ 1 900€). 
 
Pour un don de 500 USD (432 €): Nous vous offrons une réduction de 10% Une fois notre tour opérateur ouvert, vous bénéficierez d'une réduction de 10% à valoir sur le voyage de votre choix (dont les voyages sur mesures) à destination de l'Afrique Australe et sur les îles de l'Océan Indien. Par exemple, le voyage que nous proposons actuellement pour un don de 2 200 USD (environ 1 900 € / Eastern Cape en voiture pour 2 personnes) coûtera environ 2 600 USD (environ 2 250 €). Cette différence provient des charges et taxes que nous auront une fois le tour opérateur ouvert. Avec votre réduction de 10%, vous pourrez bénéficier de ce voyage au prix de 2 300 USD (environ 2 000€) .

 
Pour un don de 2 000
USD (1 730 €): Nous vous ferons découvrir le Western Cape (pour 2
personnes).Prix normal (une fois ouvert): 2 400 USD (2 000€).
Pendant 11 jours,
vous visiterez les villes suivantes: Cape Town, Hermanus, Struis Bay,
Arniston, Swellendam, Stellenbosch. Nous pensons que c'est l'idéal
pour découvrir sur une courte durée l'une des plus jolies et
célèbres régions d'Afrique du Sud.Le Western Cape est la
région la plus européenne du pays: des grandes villes, des centres
commerciaux, et des domaines viticoles. Vous n'en serez pas moins en
Afrique comme vous le rappelleront les paysages extraordinaires, les
traditions toujours présentes, ou encore l'architecture des
bâtiments d'époque. Le Western Cape, c'est également une région
riche en histoire, de l'arrivée des premiers colons (visites de
bâtiments d'époque comme le fort de Bonne Espérance) jusqu'à la
fin de l'apartheid (visite de Robben Island, ancienne prison de
Nelson Mandela), sans oublier l'histoire actuelle (visite d'un
township).Pour plus d'informations sur ce voyage, vous pouvez télécharger la brochure détaillée ici.
 
Pour un don de 2 200
USD (1 900 €): Nous vous ferons découvrir l'Eastern Cape (pour 2
personnes).Prix normal (une fois ouvert): 2 600 USD (2 250€).
Pendant 11 jours,
vous visiterez les villes suivantes: Port Elizabeth, Storms River,
The Crags, Elundini et Hogsback.Ce circuit est très orienté
vers la nature et vous emmènera dans des sites majestueux. Toutes
les activités d'extérieur sont possibles: randonnées, saut à
l'élastique (le plus haut du monde depuis un pont), accrobranche,
sandboard... Vous y trouverez forcément votre bonheur! C'est
également l'opportunité de découvrir la faune sud-africaine: un
safari dans un des plus beaux parcs du pays vous permettra d'observer
les Big
Five, ou une rencontre avec les manchots du cap, que
ce soit au hasard d'une sortie en bord de mer ou en visitant un
centre de réhabilitation qui leur est dédié. Enfin, nous vous
proposons d'en apprendre plus sur les traditions et sur le mode de
vie des locaux en séjournant dans un authentique village Xhosa:
immanquable! Pour plus d'informations sur ce voyage, vous pouvez télécharger la brochure détaillée ici.
 
Pour un don de 3 000
USD (2 590 €): Nous vous emmènerons de Cape Town à Port Elizabeth (pour
2 personnes).Prix normal (une fois ouvert): 3 500 USD (3 000€).
Pendant 15 jours,
vous visiterez les villes suivantes: Cape Town, Hermanus, Struis Bay,
Arniston, Mossel Bay, The Crags, Storms River et Port Elizabeth.Ce
circuit est un mélange des deux packs précédents. C'est l'idéal
si vous avez 2 semaines pour une première immersion dans le pays.
Vous pourrez apprendre l'histoire de l'Afrique du Sud en visitant les
musées tous plus intéressants les uns que les autres. L'un d'eux, à
Mossel Bay, vous offre l'opportunité de monter à bord d'une
véritable caravelle qui a fait le voyage entre l'Europe et l'Afrique
du Sud! Les activités en pleine nature vous permettront de découvrir
les paysages extraordinaires de la région. La découverte de la
faune n'est pas en reste: manchots, dauphins, baleines, requins,
Big Five sont à rencontrer tout au long de votre voyage. Enfin
l'immersion dans un township vous fera découvrir la vie des locaux:
nous vous avons prévu un séjour dans l'un d'eux.Pour plus d'information sur ce voyage, vous pouvez télécharger la brochure détaillée ici.Pour plus
d'informations, n'hésitez pas à nous contacter ou à consulter
notre site internet.

Retrouvez-nous sur internet

notre site internet: www.echappee-australe.com

notre page facebook: 

notre page google+: 

notre chaîne youtube: 



Quels sont les risques pour ce projet?

Le secteur du tourisme en France est très réglementé. L'objectif est de protéger au maximum le consommateur. Les conditions pour ouvrir un tour-opérateur sont les suivantes:
La compétence: un diplôme reconnu dans le tourisme et de le l'expérience. Cette condition est remplie grâce à Amandine. 

Obtenir une garantie financière dont le montant varie selon la forme du tour-opérateur (société, association, etc.). C'est la raison de notre campagne de financement participatif. Cette garantie a pour but de couvrir les clients face aux défaillances éventuelles de l'entreprise. 
1. Si nous n'atteignons pas notre objectif de campagne?Nous ferons tout pour ouvrir notre tour-opérateur. Nous avons d'autres solutions financières viables. De plus, une solution consiste à ouvrir notre agence sous forme d'association: cela ne changera rien pour nos clients mais de notre côté les coûts sont moindres.
2. Si nous n'obtenons pas la garantie financière?Il s'agit de notre principal obstacle. Nous croyons réellement en notre projet et nos proches y croient également: pour obtenir la garantie financière, ils s'engagent à hauteur de 200 000€ (par des biens immobiliers). Si malgré tout, nous n'obtenions pas cette garantie, nous nous engageons à rembourser au mieux les dons perçus (à 90% de leur valeur, Indiegogo prenant environ 10% des dons).

Si vous voyez d'autres risques, n'hésitez pas à nous en faire part afin que nous les étudiions.


FAQ - Foire Aux Questions


Les voyages proposés sont pour combien de personnes ?

Les réductions proposées sont-elles valables pour moi et mon conjoint ?
Peut-on adapter les voyages que vous proposez selon nos envies ?
Pour les voyages proposés, peut-on choisir la date qui nous convient ?
Y a t-il un surcoût en fonction de la date du voyage ?

Quelle est la meilleure période pour observer les baleines ?



1. Les voyages proposés sont pour combien de personnes?Les voyages que nous proposons via le crowdfunding sont pour 2 personnes. Ils incluent la location d'une voiture, des logements en chambre double et des activités (je vous invite à lire nos brochures pour plus d'informations). 
Par exemple, 1 don de votre part de 2 000 USD vous donnera droit à un voyage pour vous et pour votre conjoint (ou toute autre personne vous accompagnant). 

2. Les réductions proposées sont-elles valables pour moi et mon conjoint?Si vous nous faites un don vous donnant droit à une future réduction (250 USD pour 5% ou 500 USD pour 10%),  cette réduction portera sur un voyage de votre choix de notre catalogue (disponible à partir de l'ouverture de notre tour-opérateur) ou sur un voyage sur mesure. Cette réduction s'appliquera sur les prestations suivantes: logement, activités, location de voiture. La réduction s'appliquera pour un voyage pour vous, votre conjoint et pour d'autres personnes vous accompagnant (un voyage pour 4 personnes + 1 enfant en bas âge maximum). 

3. Peut-on adapter les voyages que vous proposez selon nos envies?Nous pouvons adapter le voyage à vos goûts en changeant le type de logement, en ajoutant des activités ou en le complétant par la visite d'autres lieux. Nous pourrons en discuter par email et/ou par téléphone. Dès le début, nous accordons de l'importance à ce que votre voyage corresponde à vos envies. 

4. Pour les voyages proposés, peut-on choisir la date qui nous convient?Concernant la date, il faut tout d'abord attendre que nous soyons ouverts (nous envisageons de démarrer courant Avril 2015). Les premiers voyages pourront donc se faire dès le mois de juin.

5. Y a t-il un surcoût en fonction de la date du voyage?Pour ce qui est de l'année 2015, il ne devrait pas y avoir de surcoûts (sauf en cas de grande variation des taux de change USD-Euro-ZAR). Nous avons contacté nos partenaires et les tarifs qu'ils nous ont donnés s'appliqueront normalement pour toute l'année 2015. 

6. Quelle est la meilleure période pour observer les baleines? Les baleines longent la côte sud africaine pendant l’hiver australe: de Juillet à Novembre.
Les voyage « Western Cape en autotour » et « de Cape Town à Port Elizabeth en autotour », vous emmènent à Hermanus. Les baleines y viennent en nombre et reste dans la baie. Vous pourrez les observer depuis la côte. 
Du 2 au 4 Octobre 2015, il y aura un festival dans cette ville: The Whale Festival. Nous vous conseillons d’y aller à ce moment.

story:
ONE YEAR LATER;

I've been using the HECK out of that front end loader. You betcha! I can't thank you all enough. Here we are past the spring when Inidigogo launched their InDemand program and all of the rains - and we're into another drought - if you can believe that! Not any rain to speak of since June 30th - as I type this, it's October 11th.

We lost a lot of ground to those floods, and fall is late to get planted due to the opposite problem now - no rain.

I'm hanging in here - doing my best to make lemon meringue pie from the lemony weather.

The pond is dry - and YES! I used the new loader to scoop up as much of the silt as I could. I ended up having to hire a 4wd tractor operator to really dig in and give it more depth. The pond is now 3' deeper in some areas.

I hate thieves

Last month, someone helped themselves to some of the equipment that is pertinent to the farm.

The AC/DC inverter that allows me to pump water using the solar panels - those were nailed down, so they didn't steal them.  That's about $100

My beloved oiless air generator - with all of the tires around here - you have to have one of those! $60

So many of my hand tools - you know, hammers, screw drivers, channel locks, and all of the goodies that you accumulate in your handy dandy tool box - gone-ski! Some used tools have been donated to me from a few folks - thank you! But I'm still grabbing for that extra hack saw, big ol' pair of channel locks, and odds and ends nails, screws, nuts and bolts. Let's say - about $100 worth of stuff.

Another biggie they got was my old wood handled pick axe. I'm sure it was a vintage model, but it came in handy for breaking up hard ground. (I'm hoping the thief isn't going to use it to break in doors...) $50 - at least

55-gallon plastic barrels are not free. They used one of mine to cart a bunch of stuff off in! Yep! $70

My nerves have been a bit edgy and I'd sleep a bit better if I could have a decent security camera system installed. You know, the kind that films, AND calls you so you can call the cops ASAP.... or, go greet them with your shot gun. I've priced some and we're looking at at least $500+ for the solar powered; which I need since there's not any AC power past the pond - AND I like to be green.

Add a few solar powered pole spot lights - $45 ea

And if you can believe it, they even stole the dogs' stainless steel feed bowls! Those were not cheap! $15each

My official Red Rider carbine-action 200-shot range model BB rifle with a compass in the stock was also among the items swiped. Now I have a replacement from a friend - but I think it's time for a .410 pump action shot gun, don't you? $500

All in all, I'm lucky - they let me sleep. They didn't hurt the animals. Everything that was taken is more or less replaceable. Insurance doesn't hit till they get $2k in stuff. Insurance is in case the place burns to the ground - not for thieving punks.

But add to this all of the lost crops from the spring floods - also not insurable on a small farm - and the slow summer sales and slow start to fall. Well, a boost of cash flow would be great.

I'd still like to;

  • Re-do the front yard into a free community garden. (See below under Last Fall)
  • Put a solar system w/security cameras into the yurt for classes that require power/video, etc. and to keep it all safe.
  • And I really need to hire someone to fix the barns, level the house and replace some rotting wood; upgrade the electrical all around this 100 yr old homestead and I've got a few roofs that need some real fixing that I am not going to be able to do this time. I've done repairs, but I think it's time for new. Let's estimate that at $1,000

As always - anything you can muster up is appreciated. I've helped others over the summer with my tractor, pitched in my $25 - $200 for those in need where and when I could, and that's all because of your past generosity!

We're all in this local food stuff together! Thanks!

Last Fall;

Last fall, 74 or so very generous people helped the farm acquire a front end loader, ice maker, trailer and the budget for a walk-in cooler.

The fine folks at Indiegogo unveiled a new idea recently, that allows you to continue to partner with the farm, even though the main fundraiser is over. It's called InDemand.

A small, one person run farm like this one, is always in need of something - and it's usually something that wasn't in the budget.  Like;

  • a skilled repairman,
  • a part to fix something that shouldn't have broken,
  • fencing to keep out new neighbors' new flock of goats so they don't eat my garden, irrigation supplies to expand the edible forest, or
  • other stuff that just plain wears out or breaks.

And right now with all of this rain, I'm worried about the foundation of both of the decades old barns and their leaky roofs! That's not going to be cheap to get fixed, and I'm not brave enough to jack up a 60+ year old barn by myself. LOL

And lately, with the record flooding rains, many crops have been lost, which means, sales are lost, and the budget could really use a shot in the arm.

Some projects I am working on include a Balch Springs, TX branch of the Food is Free Project community garden.  Basically, through volunteers and in any extra time I have, a garden is planted out in the front yard for members of the community, I'm thinking mostly it will be passersby, to eat from. So far, there are several fruit trees, a product of the last fund raiser's perk program, and the frame of a raised bed that will allow those with disabilities to access it.

Here is a pic of the new loader being used to fill the bed with logs for hugelkultur.

So there's some expenses associated with that like plants, seeds, more edible perennials, some more wood for additional raised beds, (one of our volunteers found this wood!), and a little budget to be able to offer snacks, water, and lunch to our volunteers would be awesome, too.

Also, in order to give our customers at the farmer's market held here a better selection of products, I'm working on the plans to put in a pallet-based covered porch on which a small chest freezer can sit for self-serve grass fed beef and pastured chicken purchases. So many small farmers are too busy to work more than 1 market, and I know this one isn't as busy as some, but our community needs good food, too.  Using pallets that I have access to through a vendor, will keep the costs down. But it would be nice to be able to compensate the handyman for his trips back and forth to help build it. Gas isn't free and he's on a fixed income.

And so far, the utility, mortgage and insurance company won't take eggs for payments, so while the budget is short due to low sales/crop losses, monthly bills still need to be paid, too.  I keep the budget pretty tight, but I do occasionally need to hit the grocery store myself. And the truck won't run on air, either.

So you see, there's always expenses. And the CSA budget is the backbone, no doubt. We're at capacity for what I feel comfortable trying to provide for, and some of those are not paying, but work/trade shares. I am always open to sliding scale arrangements for a family who wants to eat healthier.

As other means to raise capital, I also offer farm tours and I'm adding one as a perk this go round. I actually love it when classes come out to the farm and learn about where food comes from, get to pet a chicken and see a piece of native Texas prairie - nearly in their own backyards.

And, just this spring, we started yoga class in the recently acquired yurt, which also needs to be paid for. The young couple who started their off-grid living experiment in it here, rather than take it down and relocate it, decided to allow me to keep it, for a whale of a deal, when they left.


But I do still need to pay them, re-install a solar and security camera package and restore a donated wood-burning/propane kitchen stove so we can also rent it out for private dinners, cooking and other classes. The storage shed was broken into and the doors need to be replaced so tables and chairs can be kept back there for these kinds of events.

I'll be back and post updates here periodically. But the best way to keep up with Life on the Farm - is here, at the blog. Or here, on Facebook.

Anything you send is very much appreciated and needed. Small farming isn't the most lucrative business in the world, but it is the most satisfying job I've ever had.

Please help me keep the farm going so we can keep, feeding the soil - feeding the community.

Thank you very much.

Farmer Marie

The Long and the Short of It

For in-depth details of the campaign and farm's history, or the Long of It, scroll down a bit to the next video.

For the edited, quick and simple version, or the Short of It - here's the scoop;  with current updates. It will give you the basics.

10/04 - THERE IS A CURRENT CHALLENGE ON THE CAMPAIGN - A GENEROUS SUPPORTER HAS OFFERED TO MATCH ANY AND ALL CONTRIBUTIONS UP TO $5,000!! YOUR SUPPORT IS DOUBLED - JUST LIKE THAT!

10/25 - Check out the new perks! Dylan & Company candles. Dude Sweet Chocolate. PLUS another private dinner at the farm with Chef Graham Dodds of Hibiscus!
$2 gets you in to our salute to Veterans and Farmers mini-film festival Nov. 7th.

11/1 - We did it! The original goal of 10k has been met! We do still have perks up and if you would like to be part of this campaign, know that any additional funds that come in between now and the end of the campaign, will surely be used towards other farm needs. Things like solar panels, etc. for the yurt, ($1500 est), new rolls of frost cloth (yes, it gets cold in N. Texas), new seat for the tractor (the horses chewed on the old one), upgraded solar charger for new flock of chickens....with a farm, extra money always gets put to good use!

HERE'S THE START

HELP US HELP S/E DALLAS COUNTY ACCESS MORE REAL, FRESH FOOD GROWN WITH INTEGRITY!

Good, real, food, and fair access to it, is what can bring people together for the cause of helping feed a community something healthier than the fast "food" joints that are popping up all over the landscape. Often, covering over land that could have become another community garden area where fresh food was grown and distributed.

Add to that the small farm aspect of this country’s history, and its importance to a community - and the two ideas go hand in hand.

Take a small, indie farmer working hard to educate her community and make healthy food available and affordable for those who wouldn’t otherwise have access to it; that's what this fund raiser is all about.

I am a small, independent farmer living on 14 acres in Southeast Dallas County, in North Texas where I own and operate a sustainable, organic, permaculture minded farm. I grow seasonal produce for a small but loyal CSA membership and a twice a month farmer's market held right here on the farm, in the small city I live in, which lacks access to fresh, local, organic produce. I teach classes on food preparation, gardening and have interned several young people interested in farming.

In order to really be efficient, financially sustainable and grow more food for the on-farm community farmer's market, I really need a front end loader on my tractor.

This way I can make more in-house compost, which keeps the soil healthier and grows more food, and works better, plus saves money over buying bagged organic fertilizers, thereby keeping food costs lower for my neighborhood, and reducing the farm’s over all footprint.

A front end loader is not cheap, and I haven't been able to save up enough with the amount of crops I'm currently yielding. Even using organic fertilizers, the soil needs things like microbes to help break down the fertilizer. Without being able to add lots of living compost, where microbes live, the process of decomposition is painstakingly slow - and the yields are low. The soil out here is kind of like beach sand. It takes a lot of compost to make it healthy.

Besides that, just keeping the farm running month to month, with a super tight cash flow, is a challenge. Farmers are sort of like teachers and firefighters - we're not in it for the glory or the riches. ;) 

But, a loader installed on the existing tractor IS an excellent and wise investment. For the long term future of the farm, it means several steps in the right direction towards sustainability in so many ways for the farm, and the community it serves.

Therefore, I'm reaching out to people like you, far and wide through this Indiegogo crowd funding campaign, in hopes of raising enough capital to get a front end loader attached to my tractor.....it costs about four grand, plus the cost of perks, this site's campaign fees, etc.

Any farmer needs the right equipment, in order to be proficient. From tools for the soil to help ensure a bountiful harvest, to the storage equipment to keep the food they toiled to grow, fresh for the people who are going to eat it.

So I’m also trying to raise enough to help fund a walk-in cooler and ice maker to keep that food fresh.  That's about another 3k, plus perks, fees, etc.,  (Garden Café is watching an ice maker for us on an auction right now!)

And since we're always taught to "dream big", let's shoot for a 16’ utility trailer, too, once we make our current 10k goal! (Calais Winery has a beautiful trailer waiting on us – all legally titled and ready to roll!)

The trailer would be awesome, and a gift that keeps on giving, because then I can haul the tractor to help other farmers and community gardeners with a piece of equipment many don't have. The walk-in and ice machine are things other local farmers who vend here at our farmer’s market can benefit from as well.

That's the short of it.

I hope you will contribute to this campaign by choosing a perk/level on the right, and help us reach our goal - even exceed it - so we can also get the new trailer, too.

There are fun and cool perks for contributing, if you want them, or you can just savor the warm and fuzzy feeling you get when you step up and help someone do something important and wonderful - like bring awesome, nutritious, fresh produce to a food desert community by helping a small farmer do her job more effectively and efficiently.

Thank You, for checking out this project and sharing it around with others.  And remember, if we reach the full $10k goal, we save 5% in fees! I know I'll post some updates as this goes on, so be sure to check back and see how we're doing! We have 47 days, until midnight November 8th, to reach our goal.

When it was first suggested that I use a crowd-funding campaign to raise money for the farm, I was skeptical. Would total strangers want to give money to a farm they've never seen, don't know the mission of, and may never see?

But then I thought about how this farm started - through Community Supported Agriculture - which is a kind of small crowd funding model, too. CSA's help stabilize a small farm's base budget, plus help give the community food security, and it's how I was able to break ground on this farm back in 2008.

Please share this project with whoever and where ever you think folks might be interested in helping Eden's Garden CSA Farm - GROW!


UPDATE 10/22

We're nearly half way to our goal - with only 2 weeks left. It's time for the final push!! There's a great little ice maker waiting for us if we can just get there. A trailer, all legally titled and everything, awaits us in the wine country thanks to Calais Winery ready to sel us their 18' trailer. And the plans for the walk-in cooler are being reviewed right now - we've started to clear the area where it will be built.

Won't you please help us feed the community better, more efficiently, and sustainably? Thank you.

UPDATE 10/10 -  So here's where we are on our Non-GMO, Heirloom Corn Goal Cob....

Because of our generous matching challenger, we will get our loader and we're nearly at our 2nd goal! Our community garden friends are very excited at the help this will mean for them, too!

But, more harvest also means, we'll need a way to store the bounty of veggies as soon as they're harvested until they can be available for the community market.

Every neighborhood deserves super fresh food - not 2nd grade quality.

So please help us reach our next goal to raise $2500 for the materials to build a (mostly) off grid walk-in cooler.  The plans are being reviewed right now - in exchange for a dozen pastured eggs from the farm's hard working hens. Thank you to Greg & Gianna! 

PLUS - Our challenger says the matching challenge is still on - up until we raise $5,000! We still have $1476 available in matching funds! Make your contribution count double!

You are helping build an accessible, safe, food "hub" for the folks in this food desert. An oasis! 

10/08 - We Did It! YOU Did IT! We have made it to our first benchmark goal (with the matching funds added in)!! The loader means this farm can scoop manure and mulch, make it into BIG piles of compost and spread it out - MUCH more efficiently!! Here's a pic of what it will look like here soon!

I'm so excited and humbled at the same time that so many of you rallied around this project, Feed the Soil - Feed the Community!

Our next goal is $2500 for the walk in cooler materials. We'll certainly be producing more and more as the soil gets better and better and we're already currently running out of ice chests to keep the produce fresh as we harvest it.

We have a spot all picked out for it, I've been working on the plans and can't wait to have a "green" walk-in cooler that not only will keep food fresh, but use solar power and re-generate rain water to irrigate our seedlings in the greenhouse! We've got a month left in this campaign - let's do this!! (Plus, if we reach our full goal of 10k, we save 5% on the fees this platform charges.)

10/07 - We're almost at our first benchmark of $4000! Thank you - with a loader, we'll be on our way to making more compost for this farm's super sandy soil. (ever try to grow veggies in beach sand?) I'm delighted at the support and shared some of your comments in the latest update. Be sure to "follow" the campaign to get updates and details on our campaign count down party!

10/04 - THERE IS A CURRENT CHALLENGE ON THE CAMPAIGN - A GENEROUS SUPPORTER HAS OFFERED TO MATCH ANY AND ALL CONTRIBUTIONS UP TO $5,000!! YOUR SUPPORT IS DOUBLED - JUST LIKE THAT!

The Long of It;

Now, if you really want to get a feel for who I am, what I'm trying to do here in Southeast Dallas County, Texas, what this farm is all about and how you can be a part of it - please, sit back and enjoy our short, but a little longer than the above, video, and/or read on... my sweet friend Margaret did an awesome job for us on this video, and I want to show you what we're all about here at Eden's....


Who Are "We"and What Do We Need?

Eden’s Garden CSA Farm was founded in 2008 by me, Marie Tedei, with the goal of making a fair living and providing real food grown with integrity for the community in Southeast Dallas County where I had lived for nearly 20 years.

There are several low income housing apartment complexes and neighborhoods within a few miles of the farm’s front gate and only 1 grocery store that does not provide local or organic produce.

Those living south of the farm have even less access to good food, as there are nothing but gas stations and stores primarily selling beer, wine and liquor within several miles. (This is basically the definition of a USDA food desert.) 

You get the idea. We needed an oasis.

To help provide that oasis for the community, my new farming career started with a little monthly “market day”. Locals without transportation could walk, literally, to a farmer’s market at my little organic garden center, and purchase fresh food and meet the actual farmers and ranchers.

I wasn't growing food - yet - but it provided the few small, local farmers I knew, the opportunity to sell without the pricing pressures of cheap, imported foods and the wholesale food brokers they were used to at the old big city “farmer’s market” downtown.

Eden’s Market Day was one of the first, “neighborhood” markets, and is still the only all farmers, all "organic" food farmers market in DFW.

But, If You Want Something Done....

However, it became pretty clear, pretty fast, that if this market was going to be successful, and I was determined to make that happen, it meant I was going to have to use my horticultural background, change my focus and start growing produce here myself. No more landscape design. It was time to really roll up my sleeves.

The need in my community for access to fresh, local produce - grown without toxic, synthetic chemicals - tugged at both my heartstrings, my entrepreneurial and eco- friendly, tree hugging spirit.


Some still think I'm probably a little bit crazy to have quit a "real" job to make a living by farming. But this is the most consuming, disappointing, educational, interesting, monotonous, satisfying, uplifting and worthwhile "job" I've ever had. And I can't think of another job I'd rather have, instead.

(above is one of my first mentors - co-owner of HOMEsweetFARM serving Houston)

I'd already been hearing it loud and clear from other small farmers in TOFGA who couldn't understand why I wasn't already growing food, instead of boarding horses and designing xeric landscapes for a living. 

They all echoed the same thing - there just weren't enough small, local growers using organic methods in the state - or in the Dallas area.

And they were right, the demand was great - new customers were coming to the market every week looking for organically grown produce for their families. Some came via doctor’s orders, some for the fresher taste, and others just to support local, food.

So what's a girl to do?  In the fall of 2008; I broke ground and…

A Farm Was Born!

Most of the start-up capital for the modest budget came from my full time job income and people in the surrounding Dallas area that were anxious to have a small farm nearby from which they could purchase produce and bring their families to visit.

This way of supporting a farm is a model called CSA, or Community Supported Agriculture. Families pledge a portion of the budget for the farm’s needs, (labor, seeds, plant starts, supplies, and soil amendments, equipment, etc.) in exchange for a “share” of the harvest once it starts rolling in later in the year.

Fortunately, that winter I managed to acquire a reliable, fairly new, small John Deere 650 tractor with a mower attachment (or brush hog – or bush hog depending on what part of the world you’re from). And a few small implements that help a lot with soil work were also acquired that summer and later in 2012.

We Are Off to a Great Start!

Now in our 6th year, I still hold a market on the farm twice a month. And along with a handful of other small farmers and ranchers, and a local, artisan sourdough baker, I still enjoy the valid and well earned reputation this market has for only selling “clean” or organically produced food, that is also produced locally, and sold at realistic prices the community can afford.

The USDA approved our market to accept SNAP funds from customers who use federal “food stamp” benefits. This, along with sliding scale pricing for the CSA, truly makes our food accessible to anyone who strives to access fresh, local, organic food.

However

Overall the market still runs short in produce to supply the demand. I need to grow more produce to sell here to feed the community at large, and at other markets to help the farm be more financially sustainable and fund our other programs.

This community farm consists of 1 full time grower, yep, that would be me. It’s a 1-woman farm you could say. And I can only do so much with a shovel and a wheel barrow.....

What We Need

We need to make compost – and lots of it!!

The demand for a front end loader on a farm is great. Ask any farmer. The demand for one on a farm with only 1 full time grower and a handful of occasional volunteers is even greater.

A new after-market front end loader can be attached to our existing tractor. But they’re not cheap.

This is where you come in!

I'm reaching out to people far and wide through this Indiegogo crowd funding campaign,

Here's the deal, a brand new after-market loader can be attached to our existing tractor. (I've done the homework, it's too risky to find a used loader that "might" fit our tractor.) So I found a dealer to order it, a tractor mechanic to install it and they said they'll even paint it John Deere Green!

(I asked for pink, but, whatever....)

A loader here on the farm full time means much more compost can be made to feed the soil and a lot more veggies grown to feed the community.

(Not to mention all of the other heavy projects generally unattainable by 1 person.)

If we raise all the funds to buy and install a new front end loader for our tractor, (which is about 4k installed, plus the fees we have to pay for running this campaign and cost of perks, etc.), any additional funds will go towards funding our solar powered walk-in cooler, (because we're going to be growing a lot more veggies and will need a place to store them as we harvest the bounty!)

We're planning to build it ourselves using as much recycled material as feasible.

If we're still ahead of the game on this campaign with time and willing contributors left, I will purchase an ice maker to keep the veggies cold in the ice chests at market and on deliveries.  All of this, plus perks and fees, comes to about 10k

Still feeling generous? "They" tell you to have a "stretch" goal; so here's ours;

I learned the hard way that a trailer with a legal title is not as easy to come by as I hoped, nor as inexpensive as I thought. So, we'll add your funds to some we were given earlier this summer to find one, and finally buy a legally titled 16'-18' utility trailer that I can haul the tractor on, (with it's shiny new loader you helped us get, and my other tractor implements), to help community gardens and other farmers who don't have this invaluable equipment. It's the gift that keeps on giving!

What Else Can You Do? - Glad You Asked!

We can always use funds to;
  • upgrade our solar powered irrigation system
  • finish building the solar power system and build a solar powered hot water heater for our off-grid yurt classroom/eco-friendly homestead exhibit;
  • build and integrate a bigger rain catchment system to provide more rainwater for our livestock and interactive educational permaculture herb and veggie garden
  • replace frost cloth, greenhouse plastic, irrigation tapes and other supplies....

 ...............the "wish list" could go on and on. (And it does!)

Trust me, all of the funds raised, will be well used for the farm's needs!  There are critters to feed, fences to fix; a 100 year old property rarely runs out of projects. :)

PLUS - if you help me reach the full goal of $10,000, fees go down to 4%!  So we'll be able to keep and put to use more of the cash you contribute.

My main vision for this farm has always been to empower people to eat well, teach people to grow some of their own food, get them excited about farming and to make myself an honorable living. And, to do it all with transparency, integrity and sustainability so this community is proud of its farm and is around for many generations to come.


With your generous help, you can be a part of that vision, and help me make it happen! Thanks for taking a look at what we're doing here - and considering making a contribution to;  FEED THE SOIL, FEED THE COMMUNITY!

PERKS, PERKS, and MORE PERKS!

Thanks for checking out this project. Please choose from one of the fun perks to help thank you for pitching in to help raise money for the farm!

Fun Bumper Stickers & Magnets

Coffee Mug w/Noble Coyote Roasters Coupon
(back side design - Real Food, Grown with Integrity - Who's Your Farmer?)
(back side = Who's Your Farmer?
And please, share this link around your social network, email list and to whoever and where ever you think folks might be interested in helping Eden's Garden CSA Farm - GROW!

If you're local, or vacationing in Dallas, please do come see us down on the farm - each 1st, 3rd and 5th Saturday for our Market Day, April - December.

Farmer Marie
aka Eden's Gardener

Media Stories About the Farm

Dallas Observer Best Of 2013 - voted best CSA in DFW (tied)
BARN AID at Eden's 2012 - annual fund raiser held here at the farm
Pesto Salsa Challenge! 2012 - a market day favorite event
Chefs for Farmers Launch long-table style benefit dinner at Eden's. D Magazine 2011 - inaugural CFF dinner
Market Day Feature Story in NeighborsGo - July 2010
Featured in Edible Dallas & Forth Worth - Winter 2009
Market Day - Our Humble Beginnings 2007

and no, we are in NO WAY associated with the national food giant of a sort of similar name - they think people will confuse us so much as to legally ask me to stop calling my place Eden's.  I know, right?  It's Eden's Organic Garden Center and Eden's Garden CSA Farm. Thanks!
story_txt:
ONE YEAR LATER;I've been using the HECK out of that front end loader. You betcha! I can't thank you all enough. Here we are past the spring when Inidigogo launched their InDemand program and all of the rains - and we're into another drought - if you can believe that! Not any rain to speak of since June 30th - as I type this, it's October 11th. We lost a lot of ground to those floods, and fall is late to get planted due to the opposite problem now - no rain. I'm hanging in here - doing my best to make lemon meringue pie from the lemony weather. The pond is dry - and YES! I used the new loader to scoop up as much of the silt
 as I could. I ended up having to hire a 4wd tractor operator to really 
dig in and give it more depth. The pond is now 3' deeper in some areas. 
I hate thieves
Last month, someone helped themselves to some of the equipment that is pertinent to the farm. The AC/DC inverter that allows me to pump water using the solar panels - those were nailed down, so they didn't steal them.  That's about $100My beloved oiless air generator - with all of the tires around here - you have to have one of those! $60So many of my hand tools - you know, hammers, screw drivers, channel locks, and all of the goodies that you accumulate in your handy dandy tool box - gone-ski! Some used tools have been donated to me from a few folks - thank you! But I'm still grabbing for that extra hack saw, big ol' pair of channel locks, and odds and ends nails, screws, nuts and bolts. Let's say - about $100 worth of stuff.Another biggie they got was my old wood handled pick axe. I'm sure it was a vintage model, but it came in handy for breaking up hard ground. (I'm hoping the thief isn't going to use it to break in doors...) $50 - at least55-gallon plastic barrels are not free. They used one of mine to cart a bunch of stuff off in! Yep! $70My nerves have been a bit edgy and I'd sleep a bit better if I could have a decent security camera system installed. You know, the kind that films, AND calls you so you can call the cops ASAP.... or, go greet them with your shot gun. I've priced some and we're looking at at least $500+ for the solar powered; which I need since there's not any AC power past the pond - AND I like to be green.Add a few solar powered pole spot lights - $45 eaAnd if you can believe it, they even stole the dogs' stainless steel feed bowls! Those were not cheap! $15eachMy official Red Rider carbine-action 200-shot range model BB rifle with a compass in the stock was also among the items swiped. Now I have a replacement from a friend - but I think it's time for a .410 pump action shot gun, don't you? $500All in all, I'm lucky - they let me sleep. They didn't hurt the animals. Everything that was taken is more or less replaceable. Insurance doesn't hit till they get $2k in stuff. Insurance is in case the place burns to the ground - not for thieving punks. But add to this all of the lost crops from the spring floods - also not insurable on a small farm - and the slow summer sales and slow start to fall. Well, a boost of cash flow would be great. I'd still like to;
 Re-do the front yard into a free community garden. (See below under Last Fall) 

Put a solar system w/security cameras into the yurt for classes that require power/video, etc. and to keep it all safe. 

And I really need to hire someone to fix the barns, level the house and replace some rotting wood; upgrade the electrical all around this 100 yr old homestead and I've got a few roofs that need some real fixing that I am not going to be able to do this time. I've done repairs, but I think it's time for new. Let's estimate that at $1,000 

As always - anything you can muster up is appreciated. I've helped others over the summer with my tractor, pitched in my $25 - $200 for those in need where and when I could, and that's all because of your past generosity! We're all in this local food stuff together! Thanks! Last Fall;Last fall, 74 or so very generous people helped the farm acquire a front end loader, ice maker, trailer and the budget for a walk-in cooler. The fine folks at Indiegogo unveiled a new idea recently, that allows you to continue to partner with the farm, even though the main fundraiser is over. It's called InDemand. A small, one person run farm like this one, is always in need of something - and it's usually something that wasn't in the budget.  Like;
a skilled repairman, 

a part to fix something that shouldn't have broken, 

fencing to keep out new neighbors' new flock of goats so they don't eat my garden, irrigation supplies to expand the edible forest, or 

other stuff that just plain wears out or breaks. 

And right now with all of this rain, I'm worried about the foundation of both of the decades old barns and their leaky roofs! That's not going to be cheap to get fixed, and I'm not brave enough to jack up a 60+ year old barn by myself. LOL And lately, with the record flooding rains, many crops have been lost, which means, sales are lost, and the budget could really use a shot in the arm. Some projects I am working on include a Balch Springs, TX branch of the Food is Free Project community garden.  Basically, through volunteers and in any extra time I have, a garden is planted out in the front yard for members of the community, I'm thinking mostly it will be passersby, to eat from. So far, there are several fruit trees, a product of the last fund raiser's perk program, and the frame of a raised bed that will allow those with disabilities to access it. Here is a pic of the new loader being used to fill the bed with logs for hugelkultur.So there's some expenses associated with that like plants, seeds, more edible perennials, some more wood for additional raised beds, (one of our volunteers found this wood!), and a little budget to be able to offer snacks, water, and lunch to our volunteers would be awesome, too. Also, in order to give our customers at the farmer's market held here a better selection of products, I'm working on the plans to put in a pallet-based covered porch on which a small chest freezer can sit for self-serve grass fed beef and pastured chicken purchases. So many small farmers are too busy to work more than 1 market, and I know this one isn't as busy as some, but our community needs good food, too.  Using pallets that I have access to through a vendor, will keep the costs down. But it would be nice to be able to compensate the handyman for his trips back and forth to help build it. Gas isn't free and he's on a fixed income. And so far, the utility, mortgage and insurance company won't take eggs for payments, so while the budget is short due to low sales/crop losses, monthly bills still need to be paid, too.  I keep the budget pretty tight, but I do occasionally need to hit the grocery store myself. And the truck won't run on air, either. So you see, there's always expenses. And the CSA budget is the backbone, no doubt. We're at capacity for what I feel comfortable trying to provide for, and some of those are not paying, but work/trade shares. I am always open to sliding scale arrangements for a family who wants to eat healthier. As other means to raise capital, I also offer farm tours and I'm adding one as a perk this go round. I actually love it when classes come out to the farm and learn about where food comes from, get to pet a chicken and see a piece of native Texas prairie - nearly in their own backyards. And, just this spring, we started yoga class in the recently acquired yurt, which also needs to be paid for. The young couple who started their off-grid living experiment in it here, rather than take it down and relocate it, decided to allow me to keep it, for a whale of a deal, when they left. But I do still need to pay them, re-install a solar and security camera package and restore a donated wood-burning/propane kitchen stove so we can also rent it out for private dinners, cooking and other classes. The storage shed was broken into and the doors need to be replaced so tables and chairs can be kept back there for these kinds of events. I'll be back and post updates here periodically. But the best way to keep up with Life on the Farm - is here, at the blog. Or here, on Facebook. Anything you send is very much appreciated and needed. Small farming isn't the most lucrative business in the world, but it is the most satisfying job I've ever had. Please help me keep the farm going so we can keep, feeding the soil - feeding the community. Thank you very much.Farmer Marie The Long and the Short of It

For in-depth details of the campaign and farm's history, or the Long of It, scroll down a bit to the next video.
 For the edited, quick and simple version, or the Short of It - here's the scoop;  with current updates. It will give you the basics.

Good, real, food, and fair access to it, is what can bring

landscape. Often, covering over land that could have become another community

access to it; that's what this fund raiser is all about.

organic, permaculture minded farm. I grow seasonal produce for a small but

several young people interested in farming. 
In order to really be efficient, financially sustainable and grow more food
for the on-farm community farmer's market, I really need a front end loader on
my tractor. 
This way I can make more in-house compost, which keeps the soil healthier
and grows more food, and works better, plus saves money over buying bagged
organic fertilizers, thereby keeping food costs lower for my neighborhood, and
reducing the farm’s over all footprint.

with the amount of crops I'm currently yielding. Even using organic

fertilizer. Without being able to add lots of living compost, where microbes

low. The soil out here is kind of like beach sand. It takes a lot of compost to
make it healthy. 
Besides that, just keeping the farm running month to month, with a super
tight cash flow, is a challenge. Farmers are sort of like teachers and
firefighters - we're not in it for the glory or the riches. ;)  
But, a loader installed on the existing tractor IS an excellent and wise
investment. For the long term future of the farm, it means several steps in the
right direction towards sustainability in so many ways for the farm, and the
community it serves. 
Therefore, I'm reaching out to people like you, far and wide through this
Indiegogo crowd funding campaign, in hopes of raising enough capital to get a
front end loader attached to my tractor.....it costs about four grand, plus
the cost of perks, this site's campaign fees, etc. 
Any farmer needs the right equipment, in order to be
proficient. From tools for the soil to help ensure a bountiful harvest, to the
storage equipment to keep the food they toiled to grow, fresh for the people
who are going to eat it. 
So I’m also trying to raise enough
to help fund a walk-in cooler and ice maker to keep that food fresh. 
That's about another 3k, plus perks, fees, etc.,  (Garden Café is watching an ice
maker for us on an auction right now!)
And since we're always taught to "dream big", let's shoot for a
16’ utility trailer, too, once we make our current 10k goal! (Calais Winery has a beautiful trailer
waiting on us – all legally titled and ready to roll!) 
The trailer would be awesome, and a gift that keeps on giving, because then
I can haul the tractor to help other farmers and community gardeners with a
piece of equipment many don't have. The walk-in and ice machine are things
other local farmers who vend here at our farmer’s market can benefit from as
well. That's the short of it.  I hope you will contribute to this campaign by choosing a perk/level on the right, and help us reach our goal - even exceed it - so we can also get the new trailer, too. There are fun and cool perks for contributing, if you want them, or you can just savor the warm and fuzzy feeling you get when you step up and help someone do something important and wonderful - like bring awesome, nutritious, fresh produce to a food desert community by helping a small farmer do her job more effectively and efficiently. Thank You, for checking out this project and sharing it around with others.  And remember, if we reach the full $10k goal, we save 5% in fees! I know I'll post some updates as this goes on, so be sure to check back and see how we're doing! GROW! UPDATE 10/22We're nearly half way to our goal - with only 2 weeks left. It's time for the final push!! There's a great little ice maker waiting for us if we can just get there. A trailer, all legally titled and everything, awaits us in the wine country thanks to Calais Winery ready to sel us their 18' trailer. And the plans for the walk-in cooler are being reviewed right now - we've started to clear the area where it will be built. Won't you please help us feed the community better, more efficiently, and sustainably? Thank you. UPDATE 10/10 -  So here's where we are on our Non-GMO, Heirloom Corn Goal Cob....Because
 of our generous matching challenger, we will get our loader and we're 
nearly at our 2nd goal! Our community garden friends are very excited at
 the help this will mean for them, too! But, more harvest also means, we'll need a way to store the bounty of veggies as soon as they're harvested until they can be available for the community market. Every neighborhood deserves super fresh food - not 2nd grade quality. So please help us reach our next goal to raise $2500 for the materials to build a (mostly) off grid walk-in cooler. 
 The plans are being reviewed right now - in exchange for a dozen 
pastured eggs from the farm's hard working hens. Thank you to Greg &
 Gianna! PLUS - Our challenger says the matching challenge is still on - up until we raise $5,000! We still have $1476 available in matching funds! Make your contribution count double!You are helping build an accessible, safe, food "hub" for the folks in this food desert. An oasis!  10/08
 - We Did It! YOU Did IT! We have made it to our first benchmark goal 
(with the matching funds added in)!! The loader means this farm can 
scoop manure and mulch, make it into BIG piles of compost and spread it 
out - MUCH more efficiently!! Here's a pic of what it will look like 
here soon! I'm
 so excited and humbled at the same time that so many of you rallied 
around this project, Feed the Soil - Feed the Community! Our next
 goal is $2500 for the walk in cooler materials. We'll certainly be 
producing more and more as the soil gets better and better and we're 
already currently running out of ice chests to keep the produce fresh as
 we harvest it. We have a spot all picked out for it, I've 
been working on the plans and can't wait to have a "green" walk-in 
cooler that not only will keep food fresh, but use solar power and 
re-generate rain water to irrigate our seedlings in the greenhouse! 
We've got a month left in this campaign - let's do this!! (Plus, if we 
reach our full goal of 10k, we save 5% on the fees this platform 
charges.) 10/07 - We're almost at our first benchmark of 
$4000! Thank you - with a loader, we'll be on our way to making more 
compost for this farm's super sandy soil. (ever try to grow veggies in 
beach sand?) I'm delighted at the support and shared some of your 
comments in the latest update. Be sure to "follow" the campaign to get 
updates and details on our campaign count down party! 10/04 - THERE IS A CURRENT CHALLENGE ON THE CAMPAIGN - A GENEROUS SUPPORTER HAS OFFERED TO MATCH ANY AND ALL CONTRIBUTIONS UP TO $5,000!! YOUR SUPPORT IS DOUBLED - JUST LIKE THAT! The Long of It;Now, if you really want to get a feel for who I am, what I'm trying to do here in Southeast Dallas County, Texas, what this farm is all about and how you can be a part of it - please, sit back and enjoy our short, but a little longer than the above, video, and/or read on... my sweet friend Margaret did an awesome job for us on this video, and I want to show you what we're all about here at Eden's.... 

Who Are "We"and What Do We Need?
Eden’s Garden CSA Farm was founded in
2008 by me, Marie Tedei, with the goal of making a fair living and providing real
food grown with integrity for the community in Southeast Dallas
 County where I had lived
for nearly 20 years. 
There
are several low income housing apartment complexes and neighborhoods within a few
miles of the farm’s front gate and only 1 grocery store that does not provide
local or organic produce. 
Those
living south of the farm have even less access to good food, as there are nothing
but gas stations and stores primarily selling beer, wine and liquor within
several miles. (This is basically the definition of a USDA food desert.)  
You get the idea. We needed an oasis. To
help provide that oasis for the community, my new farming career
started with a little monthly “market day”. Locals without transportation could
walk, literally, to a farmer’s market at my little organic garden center, and purchase fresh food and meet the
actual farmers and ranchers. 
I wasn't growing food - yet - but it
provided the few small, local farmers I knew, the opportunity to sell without
the pricing pressures of cheap, imported foods and the wholesale food brokers
they were used to at the old big city “farmer’s market” downtown. Eden’s Market Day was one of the
first, “neighborhood” markets, and is still the only
all farmers, all "organic" food farmers market in DFW. But, If You Want Something Done....However, it became pretty
clear, pretty fast, that if this market was going to be successful, and I was
determined to make that happen, it meant I was going to have to use my
horticultural background, change my focus and start growing produce here
myself. No more landscape design. It was time to really roll up my sleeves.
The need in my community for access to fresh, local produce - grown without
toxic, synthetic chemicals - tugged at both my heartstrings, my entrepreneurial
and eco- friendly, tree hugging spirit.Some still think I'm probably a little bit crazy to have
quit a "real" job to make a living by farming. But this is the most
consuming, disappointing, educational, interesting, monotonous, satisfying,
uplifting and worthwhile "job" I've ever had. And I can't think of
another job I'd rather have, instead.(above is one of my first mentors - co-owner of HOMEsweetFARM serving Houston)I'd already been hearing it
loud and clear from other small farmers in TOFGA who couldn't understand why I
wasn't already growing food, instead of boarding horses and designing xeric
landscapes for a living.  
They all echoed the same thing - there just weren't enough small, local growers
using organic methods in the state - or in the Dallas
area. 
And they were right, the demand was great - new customers were coming to the market every
week looking for organically grown produce for their families. Some came via
doctor’s orders, some for the fresher taste, and others just to support local,
food. So what's a girl to do?  In the fall of 2008; I broke ground and…A Farm Was Born!
Most
of the start-up capital for the modest budget came from my full time job income
and people in the surrounding Dallas area that were anxious to have a small
farm nearby from which they could purchase produce and bring their families to
visit. 
This
way of supporting a farm is a model called CSA, or Community Supported Agriculture. Families pledge a portion of the budget for the farm’s needs,
(labor, seeds, plant starts, supplies, and soil amendments, equipment, etc.) in
exchange for a “share” of the harvest once it starts rolling in later in the year.


Fortunately, that winter I
managed to acquire a reliable, fairly new, small John Deere 650 tractor with a
mower attachment (or brush hog – or bush hog depending on what part of the
world you’re from). And a few small implements that help a lot
with soil work were also acquired that summer and later in 2012.We Are Off to a Great Start!
Now
in our 6th year, I still hold a market on the farm twice a month. And along with a handful of other small
farmers and ranchers, and a local, artisan sourdough baker, I still enjoy the valid
and well earned reputation this market has for only selling “clean” or
organically produced food, that is also produced locally, and sold at realistic prices the community can afford. 
The
USDA approved our market to accept SNAP funds from customers who use federal
“food stamp” benefits. This, along with sliding scale pricing for the CSA, truly
makes our food accessible to anyone who strives to access fresh, local, organic
food. 

However
Overall the market still runs short in produce to supply the demand. I need to grow more produce to sell here to feed the community at large, and at other markets to help the farm be more financially
sustainable and fund our other programs. 
This
community farm consists of 1 full time grower, yep, that would be me. It’s a
1-woman farm you could say. And I can only do so much with a shovel and a wheel barrow.....What We Need 

We need to make compost – and lots of it!! 

The
demand for a front end loader on a farm is great.
Ask any farmer. The demand for one on a farm with only 1 full time grower and a
handful of occasional volunteers is even greater. 

A new
after-market front end loader can be attached to our existing tractor. But they’re not
cheap. 
This is where you come in!
I'm reaching out to people far and wide through this Indiegogo crowd funding
campaign, 

Here's the deal,  a brand new after-market loader can
be attached to our existing tractor. (I've done the homework, it's too risky to find a used loader that "might" fit our tractor.) So I found a dealer to order it, a tractor mechanic to install it and they said they'll even paint it John Deere Green!(I asked for pink, but, whatever....) 
A loader here on the farm full time means much more compost can be made to feed the soil and a lot more veggies grown to feed the community. (Not to mention all of the other heavy projects generally unattainable by 1 person.)

If we raise all the funds to
buy and install a new front end loader for our tractor, (which is about 4k
installed, plus the fees we have to pay for running this campaign and cost of
perks, etc.), any additional funds will go towards funding our solar powered
walk-in cooler, (because we're going to be growing a lot more veggies and
will need a place to store them as we harvest the bounty!) 
We're planning to build it ourselves using as much recycled material as
feasible. If we're still ahead of the game on this campaign with time and willing
contributors left, I will purchase an ice maker to keep the veggies cold in the ice chests at market and on deliveries.  All of this, plus perks and fees, comes to about 10kStill feeling generous? "They" tell you to have a "stretch" goal; so here's ours;I learned the hard way that a trailer with a
legal title is not as easy to come by as I hoped, nor as inexpensive as I thought. So, we'll
add your funds to some we were given earlier this summer to find one, and finally buy a legally titled 16'-18' utility trailer that I can haul the
tractor on, (with it's shiny new loader you helped us get, and my other tractor implements), to help community
gardens and other farmers who don't have this invaluable equipment. It's the
gift that keeps on giving! 
What Else Can You Do? - Glad You Asked!
We can always use funds to;


upgrade our solar powered
     irrigation system 
finish building the solar
     power system and build a solar powered hot water heater for our off-grid
     yurt classroom/eco-friendly homestead exhibit;
build and integrate a bigger
     rain catchment system to provide more rainwater for our livestock and
     interactive educational permaculture herb and veggie garden
replace frost cloth,
     greenhouse plastic, irrigation tapes and other supplies....
 ...............the "wish list" could go on
and on. (And it does!)
Trust me, all of the funds raised, will be well used for the farm's
needs!  There are critters to feed, fences to fix; a 100 year old property rarely runs out of projects. :)PLUS - if you help me reach the full goal of $10,000, fees go down
to 4%!  So we'll be able to keep and put to use more of the cash you
contribute.My main vision for this farm has always been to empower people to eat well,
teach people to grow some of their own food, get them excited about farming and to make myself an honorable living. And, to do
it all with transparency, integrity and sustainability so this community is proud of its farm and is around for many
generations to come. With your generous help, you can be a part of that vision, and help me make it
happen! Thanks for taking a look at what we're doing here - and considering
making a contribution to;  FEED THE SOIL, FEED THE COMMUNITY!PERKS, PERKS, and MORE PERKS!Thanks for checking out this project. Please choose from one of the fun perks to help thank you for pitching in to help raise money for the farm! 

Fun Bumper Stickers & Magnets





Coffee Mug w/Noble Coyote Roasters Coupon(back side design - Real Food, Grown with Integrity - Who's Your Farmer?)

(back side = Who's Your Farmer?


And please, share this link around your social network, email list and to whoever and where ever you think folks might be interested in helping Eden's Garden CSA Farm - GROW! 

If you're local, or vacationing in Dallas, please do come see us down on the farm - each 1st, 3rd and 5th Saturday for our Market Day, April - December. 
Farmer Marie
aka Eden's GardenerMedia Stories About the FarmDallas Observer Best Of 2013 - voted best CSA in DFW (tied)BARN AID at Eden's 2012 - annual fund raiser held here at the farmPesto Salsa Challenge! 2012 - a market day favorite eventChefs for Farmers Launch long-table style benefit dinner at Eden's.

D Magazine 2011 - inaugural CFF dinnerMarket Day Feature Story in

NeighborsGo - July 2010 Featured in

Edible Dallas & Forth Worth - 
Winter 2009Market Day 
- Our Humble Beginnings 2007and no, we are in NO WAY associated with the national food 
giant of a sort of similar name - they think people will confuse us so 
much as to legally ask me to stop calling my place Eden's.  I know, 
right?  It's Eden's Organic Garden Center and Eden's Garden CSA Farm. Thanks!

story:
WHO ARE WE

We are Refresh Aquamassage, a new venture raising start up capital to open the first Aquamassage in the area.  We will be using the start up funds for


We have purchased our machine and are ready for opening day!

LOCATION - UPDATE!

We have found our location! We will be located at the Dixie / 401 Flea Market! 5150 Dixie Rd, Mississauga, ON. Look for us at Booth E-325!

Our hours will be as follows:

Saturday 10 am - 6 pm

Sunday 10 am - 6 pm

We will update you again to let you know about our Grand Opening!

WHY HAVE AN AQUAMASSAGE?

Using our proven technology, we offer clients the same health benefits of a traditional hour-long massage in only 20 minutes.

Aquamassage harnesses the power of water to help people enter a perfect state of mind and body, for a feeling of well-being and renewal.  Our sophisticated dry water massage technology lets you easily select the preprogrammed massage service to suit your unique requirements, such as stronger pressure on the lower back and gentle pressure in the neck region.  For clients who desire more individual control over their experience, a handheld control enables the client to pause the massage jets on a desired location, increase or decrease the pressure in any zone, and select any single or double direction effects of massage for optimum pain relief and/or relaxation.

Virtually anyone can feel a need for massage.  Numerous research studies have documented that massage has an impressive range of physical, mental and emotional benefits.  Massage has long been recognized as a valuable method of physical and psychological healing and rejuvenation offering user preventative and curative treatment.

Our massage system technology divides the body into 12 equal zones, ranging from the feet to the neck. Pressure and pulsation frequency of the massage jets can be independently and easily programmed for each zone. Entering the height of clients automatically adjusts the length of the 12 zones to match body proportions.

Using the automatic “Gentle Start” option gradually increases the water pressure and/or pulsating frequency for a smooth introduction to your massage. The “Gentle Finish” setting automatically decreases the pulsating frequency for a relaxing ending.

AQUAMASSAGE BENEFITS

  • Clients remain clothed and dry for privacy and comfort with no post-session clean-up of oils or contaminated water

  • The spray bar travels forward and back massaging the full length of the body or easily selected to concentrate on a specific area

  • The waterjets simulate a fingertip massage from the center of the body to the sides of the body. The force can be adjusted to suit the sensitivity of the client and with a consistency that cannot be duplicated by manual massage or other massage devices.

  • The pulsating jets can be adjusted from a relaxing 2 cycles per second up to an invigorating 10 cycles per second. The pulsation can be varied independent of water pressure for maximum effect and client sensitivity.

  • The water temperature can be adjusted from approximately 90°F to 104°F using the electronic thermostat

ABOUT JOANNE SAMMS - The Team Captain and President of Refresh Aquamassage

My vision for Refresh Aquamassage started 4 years ago after a visit to the Cloud 9 Aquamassage in the West Edmonton Mall.  Tired from walking around the humongous mall, I spied the Aquamassage machines and wanted to give them a try. I came out of that machine feeling refreshed and rejuvenated and knowing that I had to find a place to have this experience back in Brampton.  I was disappointed that there were no Aquamassage machines around the Brampton area and vowed at that time to  bring them to Brampton not just for me, but for everyone else here that I know will benefit once Refresh Aquamassage is ready! Well, the time has come! I have taken a huge leap forward in this venture with the purchase of the first Aquamassage machine. As I work toward the 2nd machine for opening day, I envision the smiles on people’s faces when they come out of the Aquamassage machine with less stress, less pain and an overall sense of well being.

With more than ten years experience as a Facility Manager for some large organizations, as well as a business owner and business consultant, I have the skills and qualifications necessary to see this project through to opening day and to run a successful business going forward. I look forward to serving the community with the benefits of Refresh Aquamassage for many years to come.

I hope that after looking through the campaign, you share the vision and that you will donate to our start up.  Of course you can help by making a financial contribution, but, you can also help by getting the word out and sending our Indiegogo Campaign to as many people as you possibly can.  By Facebook, by Email, by Twitter or by 2 cups and a string, whatever social media you use can help us to get the word out and can help us reach our goal. 

We think we have some really great perks and we think everyone we know would benefit from a great massage! We look forward to getting feedback about our campaign and about the videos and perks. We would also love to answer any questions you have about Refresh Aquamassage.

We thank you in advance for your help, your support and your donations!
